PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, will be absent from question time today. Senator Herron is in Melbourne attending the Australian Reconciliation Convention. During his absence, I will take questions relating to his portfolio.

—My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, how do you explain the fact that the only results from your government's $1.7 billion public health insurance incentives package have been a continuous and growing exodus from private health insurance and continuing increases in private health insurance premiums? Minister, isn't your $1.7 billion investment aimed at increasing the numbers in private health insurance and reducing premiums? If so, why is your policy proving to be such a colossal and costly failure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The question should have been: why is such a policy necessary? The policy is necessary because 13 years of quite deliberate running down of the private sector has meant that the Medicare scheme was set up by its founders with a substantial reliance on people who could afford to support themselves in terms of health care. That was the way Labor set it up. Those who had the stewardship of Medicare over the succeeding 12 years or so in fact let the founders—the architects of the scheme—down. The architects understood very well that, without a substantial proportion of people insuring themselves, the public system would be overburdened. So the question, of course, was the wrong question.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health and Family Services has pointed out that there has in fact been a disappointing decline to 32.5 per cent of participation rates in private health insurance in the March quarter. I well remember, during the time that I was shadow health minister, pointing out similar declines to successive health ministers. It did not make much difference—under Labor, nothing was done.

The decline from 33.2 per cent in the previous quarter is not unusual when compared with the March quarter trend over the last several years. Such a decrease is hardly surprising, Senator, given that during the March quarter a very senior member of the Australian Medical Association made the irresponsible claim that people were better off without private insurance.

In addition, the opposition, and particularly the member for Dobell, continue to publicly badmouth private health insurance every chance they get in order simply to get cheap political mileage without thought of what it is doing to the health care of the nation. For a political party that did everything they possibly could while they were in government to destroy private health insurance, it is simply astounding to see that they have suddenly developed an interest in the subject. I will remind them that they had a Prime Minister who gloated in the fact that he was reliant on the public system, he and all five of his dependants.

The member for Dobell has recently claimed that the government's private health insurance incentives scheme has failed. The fact that seems to escape the member for Dobell is that the scheme has not yet started: it starts on 1 July this year, and to say that it has failed before it has even started defies commonsense.

The fact is that these incentives will make private health insurance more affordable for those members of the health funds who most need assistance in paying their premiums. Putting the money into the public system, as the member for Dobell seems to advocate, will do nothing for those people nor will it help restore the necessary balance between the public and the private health systems which, as I said at the beginning, was the original architecture of this scheme. It relied on the twin pillars of public and private financing of the health system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, your scheme is an incentive one, one designed to attract people back into private health insurance or to stay in health insurance. Minister, you have been in government for over 12 months now. Is it not true that the 0.7 per cent drop in the number of people with private health insurance in the March quarter is the highest quarterly drop for two years? Is it not true that, during this same period, your government has continued to approve massive increases in health insurance premiums, in some cases in excess of 22 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the senator understands how health funds operate. Under the legislation which they introduced and managed—or mismanaged, according to your perspective—over succeeding years, they were required to see that the health insurance funds did not fail. They had to retain by law a percentage of their reserves so that claims made by their members could be honoured.

ANSWER.PARA: I am wondering whether the senator would have had the minister for health refuse to approve those requests for increase. The previous government never knocked anything back; they did not even have any sense that the funds should be protected. Nevertheless, if we are going to make sure that the members of health funds do get what they insure themselves for, the premium increases have to be approved. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, the budget forecasts continuing strong growth in business investment over 1997-98. Will you inform the Senate of the results of today's ABS capital expenditure survey and their consistency with the budget forecast and longer term benefits of investment in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Gibson, for that important question. The government is very pleased indeed about the investment outlook for this country. Strong investment growth now provides the wherewithal for strong future growth and activity and jobs and by building up Australia's stock of capital goods and infrastructure.

ANSWER.PARA: The government is very pleased that this investment is occurring in a period where low inflation has been entrenched. Low inflation means that investment is now more likely to be based on sustainable factors, producing real value rather than speculative investments of the type we witnessed too often, I believe, in the late 1980s. Today's ABS March quarter capital expenditure survey referred to by Senator Gibson is very welcome news on the investment front. It supports the budget forecast of continuing strong investment.

The data released today show that new capital expenditure has risen 18.6 per cent over the year to March, which is simply a sensational figure—no question about it—and total business investment in the March quarter was the highest recorded since the survey's inception in 1987. They also show that the second estimate of expected capital expenditure in 1997-98 is 15 per cent higher than the first estimate taken earlier this year.

There is no doubt that the government's policies are helping to provide a better environment for business to plan and invest. Firstly, we are putting in place responsible budgetary policies and, by working towards balancing the budget, we are of course taking pressure off interest rates. We are also reforming Australia's outdated and inefficient industrial relations system with the Workplace Relations Act and, by removing small business employers from the unfair dismissal provisions, there should be a further boost for employing in small business.

We are providing significant tax relief to small business, including of course reducing the provisional tax uplift factor, freeing small business from capital gains tax on the rollover of assets on businesses and, of course, we have kept our promise not to raise taxes or increase existing taxes. In short, we are providing business with a vastly improved environment for investment and to assist in the creation of jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are in recession!

—Senator Cook, what did Labor do in its 13 years? All you did was tie up small business in more and more red tape. You raised taxes, imposed a raft of new levies on small business and—the greatest insult of all, I have to say—appointed Senator Schacht as the Minister for Small Business. The Labor Party showed its profound contempt for small business. Of course, during Labor's period of office, the interest rates available to small business rose to over 20 per cent. If Senator Gibson wishes to ask me some further questions on interest rates, I have some good news for him.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I would be interested in knowing the government's views on future interest rates.

—I raise a point of order. Given the previous rulings you have made in relation to supplementary questions, I was in fact wondering—and I am sure others might be too—whether that supplementary question was in order.

—I think it is highly doubtful if that and others have been in order in recent times on both sides for a number of points of view. We either have to continue with supplementaries as proper supplementaries, which would be a big change all round, or continue as we are. My preference would be to return to proper supplementary questions. I will allow the question on this occasion, but I think it is time that we all reviewed the manner in which we ask supplementary questions.
—Will the same apply to points of order?
—The same would apply to points of order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President. Indeed I have good news on the interest rate front today. The ANZ, some 1½ hours ago, announced that it had joined Aussie Home Loans, Priority One and Rams, in passing on the interest rate cut which was announced last Friday in full—and some. The ANZ's standard variable rate, which is now 6.99 per cent, is equal to the Aussie Home Loans rate.
—Lowest for 25 years.

—As my colleague Senator Parer said, this is the lowest rate for over a quarter of a century. This is unambiguously good news for families and good news for people in business. We hope that the other three banks will also join in offering lower interest rates as well.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, didn't you grossly mislead the Australian public when you said on Lateline on 15 May that child‐care centres who put up fees earlier this year `really had no justification for putting them up at all, because the government measures come in the middle of the year'? Had you forgotten or did you deliberately omit to tell viewers that the 50-hour cap for child‐care assistance, the reduction in the cut‐offs for families with two or more children in child care, and the abolition of the $30 income disregard all came into payment effect on 1 April this year? Do you really maintain that these measures provide no justification at all for fee increases? And why can't you simply be honest with the public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, what a stupid sort of a thing to ask! The fact is that child‐care centres in this country were putting up their fees in January prior to the changes being introduced. Senator, you want to get your facts straight.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Senator Patterson, maintain order!

—Thank you, Madam President. Senator Ian Macdonald asked whether the supplementary will be in the form of an apology. I would think that it would probably be a bit too much to ask when it is very clear that there has been a concerted campaign, particularly by Labor women, in conjunction with the child‐care union and union members. There has been a gross and mischievous misrepresentation of the government's position to parents. It is cruel. It is one more example of the way this opposition treats people who may find it difficult to get information because of the barrage of misinformation coming from the opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: Thanks to the opposition's little exercise on parents, there would be very few people who realise that the amount of money spent on child care in the first year of this government went from just over $1 billion under the Keating government to $1.1 billion in the first year. That is an increase of $100 million or a 10 per cent increase over the previous year. This year the funding on child care will be $1.146 billion and over the next four years this government is going to spend $4.8 billion. Child care is to continue to grow at three per cent real growth in each of the next four years. How many people would know, if they listened to the Labor women, that since coming to office we have created 31,222 new child‐care places at a full‐year cost of $86 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many have you taken away?
—Order! There are far too many interjections on my left. Senator Newman is entitled to give the answer.

—They do not want the public to hear the truth. That is the trouble, Madam President. In addition, we have made available a further $31 million over four years to ensure that children with high levels of additional needs get appropriate access to child‐care options, options that they were kept from during the years of the Labor government. Those are hardly the actions of a government that is trying to cut child care.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the previous government, there was an unplanned, unchecked growth in child care that did not supply the need. There was an oversupply in some areas, an under supply in others, and that has created viability problems for a number of child‐care centres. The Minister for Family Services, Mrs Moylan, has provided substantial dollars to help those child‐care centres get advice so as to make their businesses viable and continue to thrive.

BREAK.PARA: This government has also consulted widely and developed a national planning framework for child care, something, again, which the previous government did not do with parents and child‐care centres. In addition, a number of services have had excessive charging practices in place. The government is determined to establish a high‐quality child‐care system that remains flexible, affordable and accessible to families so as to enable parents to participate in the work force, if that is their choice. It is not the government's role to subsidise child‐care centres whose charging practices are excessive or inefficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can we assume from your statement on Lateline , Minister—I will repeat it—`really had no justification for putting them up at all, because the government measures come in the middle of the year,' that there will be further justification for child‐care fee increases from the middle of this year due to the removal of operational subsidies from community based, long day care centres; is it true we can expect a second round of fee increases as a result of your anti‐child‐care policies; or are you going to absolve yourself from any blame and just bash the industry like you colleague, Minister Moylan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to have escaped the senator's notice that her government was paying for child care and getting the taxpayer, therefore, to subside child care for hours that were not being used by any children at all. If you think that is being harsh, it is not our idea of being harsh: you have to be fair to the taxpayer as well as fair to the families out there earning an income and needing child care. In relation to the 50 hour cap that the senator referred to in her question, in fact, we announced in the last budget that most women with young children who work part time do not use five days of care. In addition, only 10 per cent of all centres around Australia are open for 60 hours or more a week. Yet the government, over a number of years has been subsidising a number of child‐care centres for hours that were not being used. It would be improper for us not to take action on that. The introduction of that cap was about addressing excessive charging practices by some child‐care centres. It was not about increasing child‐care fees. (Time expired)

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of a parliamentary delegation from Bangladesh. On behalf of senators, I welcome you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both enjoyable and informative.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, yesterday you launched the fourth Gas Supply and Demand Study which forecast that demand for Australia's natural gas would triple both internationally and domestically by the year 2030. Minister, what action is being undertaken now by both the government and industry to see Australia maximise exploration and expansion of our gas industry to meet this enormous demand; also, what role will natural gas play in the development of downstream industry in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Eggleston very much for that question. It is most appropriate that he would ask a question like that because Senator Eggleston, before he came into this place, was a member of the Pilbara Development Commission, which was concerned with economic development of the resource rich area within the Pilbara. Senator Eggleston must get great satisfaction from the success he achieved when on that commission.

ANSWER.PARA: The development of a natural gas industry is a success story. After 14 months of good government, it is our government that has provided the economic climate, the economic stability and the incentive to give investors and producers the confidence to commit to billion dollar projects associated with this very important industry. The newest of these is the announcement just last week by Wood side and Shell that they are proceeding with a feasibility study for a large LNG export and domestic supply project which they expect to locate in Darwin. The study will take 18 months, which, when we look at the scale of this operation—a $10 billion project—is a short—
Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten billion.
—Yes, but it's a feasibility study you are talking about.

—Senator, I agree with you: it is. What it will do, though, and this has been made very clear by the project operators, is offer, if it goes ahead—and we will be doing everything in our power to make sure it does go ahead—some 2,000 jobs during construction. When fully operational, it will provide Australia with $1.5 billion in export income yearly—in other words, it will be yet another attack on the foreign debt which we inherited from those people opposite after 13 years in government—and it will increase GDP by one percentage point. The project offers great opportunities for downstream processing in, of course, Darwin, the Northern Territory and Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The project gives me the perfect opportunity to demonstrate how a government can operate as a team player with industry. Woodside and Shell will be supported, as will other major projects falling within my portfolio responsibilities, by a new facilitation division which I have established within my department. That division is there to cut through red tape, remove roadblocks and get things moving. That is where the jobs are, and that is how we can increase overseas earnings to ensure our foreign debt remains Labor's legacy. The division will be working closely with the Prime Minister's major facilitator Bob Mansfield as well as facilitating new minerals and energy projects.

Another major project which is of great interest to Australia is the proposal to pipe gas from Papua New Guinea. That, of course, is the Chevron proposal to build a pipeline right through to Gladstone and link it with established networks along the way.

BREAK.PARA: In relation to the proposal for this pipeline, only two days ago I designated Chevron to my colleague Senator Hill as a proponent for an environmental impact assessment. It is conceivable that in the not too distant future gas may well flow through to the Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide markets. This is another project borne of confidence in the coalition government's good economic management.

Another project of great interest and one I inspected recently is the methane gas drainage project in Central Queensland, my home state. As a matter of interest, one particular operator there, Conoco, has over the past 12 months spent $30 million on that project. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister tell us whether or not there will be any third party access to these gas proposals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is moving to ensure third party access to pipelines, and this is being done through the access code, part of the gas reform process. Yesterday I announced the appointment of Mr Lee Clifford as the gas reform implementation leader. He will provide strategic leadership and oversight in the crucial final decision making phase of the gas reform process.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the reasons I have appointed Mr Clifford, who is fairly well known in the mining industry, is that I have been concerned for some time about the slowness of the process of gas reform. The appointment of Mr Clifford is to move that process along. He will help resolve key issues by direct liaison with me, the Prime Minister, premiers and territory ministers. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I ask: is the government taking any, and if so what, steps to preserve the rights people have under the Privacy Act and the Freedom of Information Act when the functions public authorities carry out are outsourced to private entities? As I understand it, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has held recently that the Freedom of Information Act is not applicable to documents held by a private contractor to a public body where the public body has asked the private body to do work previously done by it. I do not know the name of the decision—the minister may have that—but it is the decision with respect to information held by a private contractor to the Commonwealth Research and Development Corporation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Cooney, for yet another of your usual charmingly delivered questions.
—Oh! Give us a kiss.
—Well you may weep. There is an opportunity for you to follow. Ask in a charming way and you will receive.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a good question, Senator Cooney, going to matters perhaps not appreciated by some of your colleagues who are catcalling at the moment. The government does recognise the importance of protecting individual privacy and providing access to documents under the Freedom of Information Act. Any steps to contract out or privatise government functions will take into account the importance of protecting privacy and providing access to documents under the FOI Act.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to privacy protection, I understand the Minister for Finance has recently given an undertaking to consult with the Privacy Commissioner in relation to the outsourcing of computer functions. Moreover, the government has recently decided, in the context of considering a whole of government information technology infrastructure, that the Privacy Act will be amended to apply the act to contractors supplying services to government in relation to personal information held by them on behalf of the government.

The government's decision in relation to outsourcing does not indicate an intention to reduce current protections relating to matching of data by other agencies. That is as much information as I have at the moment, Senator. Irrespective of whether you feel there is more, I will ask the Attorney whether there is anything he wants to add to that and come back to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the government consider delaying the outsourcing of functions until proper protections are put in place under the Privacy Act and the Freedom of Information Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unfamiliar with the possible coordination between the outsourcing decision and those changes. But outsourcing is expected to reduce the need for savings in other areas, so there is a good reason for proceeding with outsourcing. Of course, if there is a willing Senate, legislation, as you know, Senator, gets through this place much more quickly.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, I refer to this month's alleged discoveries of fireblight on plant material in two Australian states. Do you recall that when the Australian Democrats raised concerns about Australia's quarantine services last year you accused us of preaching doom and gloom? I hope that you are not so flippant about quarantine now that some Australian orchardists are losing massive amounts of interstate trade from the fireblight scare. New Zealand apple growers are clearly entertaining fresh hopes that Australia will lift import bans on their produce following their claims that fireblight is present in Australia. New Zealand media yesterday reported that those hopes have been boosted by a new study sponsored by the governments of New Zealand and the United States which claim that mature fruit does not transmit fireblight. Can you reassure Australia's $269 million apple and pear industries—(Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the minister that tests have confirmed the presence of fireblight in plants in the Melbourne Royal Botanic Gardens and the Adelaide Botanic Gardens. There is no previously recorded incidence of fireblight in Australia and, at this stage, there is no evidence that the disease has spread beyond the Melbourne and Adelaide botanic gardens. Surveys for the disease are under way in all states, but it may be several weeks before the distribution of the disease is established. Tests are not fully consistent with the virulent fireblight and it is possible that a less virulent form is involved in these outbreaks. However, the only responsible action is to treat these outbreaks as fireblight until the status of the bacterial strain involved in these outbreaks is resolved. Samples for independent confirmation of the Australian test results have been sent to Professor Klaus Geider at the Max Planke Institute in Germany. Professor Geider is expected to visit Australia in early June to further verify test methodology.

ANSWER.PARA: A review of the possible entry path of the disease is under way. At this stage, there is no suggestion that the disease could have entered through formal quarantine clearance systems. Inadvertent transmission of the disease, for example on clothing or entry illegally on infected cuttings, is a possibility that is being investigated.As a precaution against further spread of the disease, all states have banned the entry of host material, including fruit from Victoria and South Australia. These bans are expected to be lifted in the coming weeks as survey programs establish the distribution of the disease. Eradication action by removal of diseased plants is under way in Melbourne and Adelaide.Australia's trading partners are being kept fully informed on this issue and there is no known disruption of Australia's export trade. There is no technical reason for this finding to affect export market access for Australian fruit. With respect to your final question, Australia will continue to undertake rigorous scientific analysis of import requests in line with our conservative quarantine policy. As to whether or not the ban continues, that will be dependent on scientific analysis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Minister, for that answer. Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. One of the New Zealand scientists who claimed to discover fireblight has called on the Australian government to apologise for having an inadequate quarantine service. What is your response to that, and will the Australian government be apologising for our quarantine service? I hope not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to your first question is `nonsense', and the answer to your second question is `no'.

—With some trepidation I address my question to the Minister representing the Attorney‐General. Minister, are you aware that the Victorian Police Commissioner, Mr Comrie, stated last week that the fact that Victoria is awash with heroin indicates that our barrier controls are not working. Won't this continued influx of heroin result in, as the commissioner has indicated, more addicts, more deaths, more crime, more family breakdowns and high social and financial costs, with the state police able to do little to prevent the flow of heroin that caused these costs? If so, why has the government cut $37.6 million from the budget of the Australian Federal Police over the last two years, with the latest cuts expected to see the loss of over 100 Federal Police jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I do not have a brief with respect to that particular report, and I have not seen it. Nonetheless, I do not know that you need to have bothered making your general remarks with respect to the inflow of illicit drugs such as heroin into Australia, because I do not think that anyone here would disagree. The havoc that is wrought—especially on young Australians, but on others as well—by the use of illicit drugs is very substantial and difficult to quantify in both economic and social terms but, nonetheless, agreed by everybody as being a blight on the landscape that we do not need. This government, along with all state governments, is doing everything it can with respect to those matters and other criminal activity.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, you lead then into the real point of your question. You are seeking to raise the point that because there are any drugs coming into the country it is inappropriate to reduce funding to any law enforcement agency whatsoever. That is the link you seek to make by saying, `Oh, I have a report on this hand saying that heroin is coming into the country; I have a report on the other hand that says that the AFP has been cut; you people must be in favour of drug dealers!' That is the assumption you want people to come to—or the link, presumably, you want to make. If you do not want to make that assumption, at least you want to say this: that while there are drugs coming into the country, no law enforcement agency should suffer any reduction.

This government happens to disagree. This government believes that, just because money is spent, it does not mean that it is spent efficiently and effectively. It is possible to do the same job—and frequently a better job—with a lesser amount of funding. Nonetheless, as to the detail of that particular amount of reduced funding that you referred to, I will ask the Attorney for an answer. If there is anything he wants to add to what I have already had to say, I will come back to you with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I refute the assertion that Senator Vanstone attributes to me in asking the question I asked. If the Commissioner of the Victoria Police attributes it in that way, he certainly is entitled to. I do not do it, but I have, with some disturbance, witnessed the finding on the streets of Perth of a number of bodies of young people who had died as a result of the importation of heroin into this country. I thank you for your promise that you will take the matter up with the Attorney. Can you also ask him to explain why, despite the additional $27 million that the AFP will spend on security for the Olympics, the AFP will between now and the turn of the century have over $109 million less to spend on investigating other crimes under Commonwealth law than they would have had if Labor had remained in office? How are you going to explain to Australian families that their safety and security is just another non‐core commitment as far as this government is concerned?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
QUESTION.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you for that supplementary question, because you give me an opportunity to remind you of something. The higher education sector is under the misunderstanding that Labor's forward estimates were a guarantee of money. And you ought to understand, Senator, that Labor's forward estimates—as you say, money that the AFP would have got if you had stayed in power—were blank cheques on an empty bank account. That is what you were sitting on. We have taken that empty bank account and we have turned around a $10 billion deficit over a period of three or four years into a surplus of about $1.4 billion or $1.6 billion. The consequence of that fiscal responsibility is reflected in interest rates, which are reflected in more money in people's pockets and greater business investment and will be reflected in long‐term—

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. I am not sure what part of my question Senator Vanstone is addressing herself to. I did ask a supplementary question. I did mention the bodies of young Australians littering the streets in Perth. I am not going to point the finger now but, Minister, you do need to address some of the matters raised in this question and the supplementary question.

—The part I was addressing was the senator's assertion about money that the AFP would have had if Labor had been returned. As for the reference to bodies on streets, Senator, no‐one on this side has ever pointed the finger over your side and blamed you for all the deaths while you were in government. It is a cheap shot, and you want to think about it before you make it again. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the minister aware that, following the government's decision to abandon its superannuation co‐contribution scheme, prominent superannuation academic Professor David Knox has said that Australia's retirement incomes policy reminds him of a train loaded with sheep and headed to port. As a result of a raft of changes, the final destination is unclear and the sheep are rather confused. Given the number of changes that have occurred with superannuation during the past decade—including the past 12 months—the metaphor appears apt. I therefore ask what plans the government has to inject stability into the area of superannuation and set levels of contributions which will provide decent retirement incomes for those who have reached the end of their working lives.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Assistant Treasurer

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam President, and thank you to Senator Colston for that question. Senator, you quoted some remarks by Professor Knox. I am not aware of those particular remarks.
—Wasn't he a Liberal Party adviser?

—My question is to Senator Alston, Minister for Communications and the Arts. ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

Many of the dreaming stories, the mythologies, the morals and the beliefs of Aboriginal people are increasingly finding their way into permanent art forms.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is very important to recognise that, since that 1967 referendum, it is only about 25 years since Geoffrey Bardon established an art school at Papunya that led to the modern notion of desert art which, I think, has captured the imagination not only of all Australians, both indigenous and non‐indigenous, but also of very many people overseas who come to this country and increasingly regard Aboriginal arts and culture as a vitally important memento of their visits.

Something of the order of 50 per cent of tourist spending in this country—in other words about $100 million a year—is currently spent on Aboriginal arts and craft, and that is why it is very important indeed that the Australian government should support, in every possible way, the emergence and the flowering and the development of Aboriginal art in its various manifestations.

Certainly, I can say from personal experience that, at Lajamanu, for example, a few years ago there were problems in funding the Aboriginal art coordinators. The place was basically falling to pieces. ATSIC, to its credit, was able to find additional funding and, as a result, the new coordinator there, Brent Hocking, who is only in his early 20s, has been able to discover a means, by putting on discos, of raising something of the order of $2,000 a week which goes into recycling and promoting Aboriginal art. The government certainly is very supportive in a number of areas. That is why, unlike our predecessors, we are pressing ahead with the National Museum, why we allocated $7 million in the recent budget and why we have committed something of the order, in indicative terms, of $133 million to see the completion of that very important major project. An integral part of that, in conjunction with the aspects relating to Australian society and history and our interaction with the environment, will be the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural and heritage elements.

The gallery of Aboriginal Australia will not only be a significant part of the National Museum but it will be located on the same site. This is very much in accordance with the wishes of the locals, who see that as symbolising an important step in the reconciliation process. The Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies will also be co‐located with the National Museum. The cultural industry development program, with pilot projects such as those orchestrated by Desart in central Australia and ANCA in Arnhem Land, are again very important aspects and are very much supported by the government.

In terms of copyright, we are currently developing a framework for the protection of indigenous intellectual property. We violently opposed the attempts of Paul Keating and his mates to forcibly relocate the National Aboriginal and Islander Skills Development Association from Sydney to Brisbane against their wishes. We are now working on a solution for accommodation problems with the New South Wales government.

So, in a number of very important ways, we are acknowledging the unique contribution of Aboriginal art and Aboriginal culture. I see that as a very important part of the reconciliation process and I very much hope we will continue to have the support we have garnered from the wider arts community to press ahead with a number of those initiatives that our predecessors could not afford. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. On 13 May 1997 the minister assured me that:

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Stott Despoja. The Prime Minister's announcement with respect to privacy included the announcement that the services of the Privacy Commissioner would be made available to assist business in the development of voluntary codes and to meet privacy standards. I have not been advised of any change to that, but I do have some information from the Attorney on how one might proceed to actually implement that in an effective way.

ANSWER.PARA: These ideas were canvassed by the Attorney at a banking law and practice conference on 22 May. One approach to developing a voluntary approach to privacy protection in the private sector would be to continue to develop such codes for particular sectors or to cover particular functions. Alternatively, you could have one overall set of privacy principles appropriate for application across the entire private sector.

In the first approach—which is really an incremental one—if that were to be pursued, there would be advantages in pursuing functional rather than sectoral codes. By functional codes, the Attorney means codes applying to a particular type of information or a particular use of information rather than those focusing on who in particular was using it. Nonetheless, that choice would be there. Functional codes are better suited to having continued relevance to an evolving private sector.

The second approach is that an overall set of privacy principles might be an even better approach at least as a first step. That would involve a uniform privacy standard across the entire private sector. Consumers could expect the same essential privacy protection in relation to all dealings with the private sector. Businesses would know that all players, even their direct competitors, would be playing by the same rules. Such an overall set of privacy principles would also provide a basic starting point should the development of more detailed codes specifically addressing issues relevant to particular types of information or functions later prove desirable.

That overall approach is the one that has been taken in Canada. Under the auspices of the Canadian Standards Association, a committee developed a model code for the protection of personal information. The committee was made up of a wide range of business, consumer and government representatives. It included people from the Canadian Bankers Association, insurance groups, the Canadian Direct Marketing Association, communications and information technology groups and consumer groups, such as the Consumers Association of Canada, the Public Interest Advocacy Centre and others.

The model code was approved by the Canadian Standards Council as the national standard in December 1995 and, more recently, the Canadian Standards Association has proposed to the International Standards Organisation that it develop an international standard on privacy. Both our domestic experience to date in developing sectoral and functional codes and the Canadian experience must be taken into account in our pursuit of a voluntary approach to privacy protection in the private sector.

The Privacy Commissioner is currently meeting with business and consumer groups to discuss how she might facilitate the best voluntary approach to privacy for Australia at this point in time. I am sure the Attorney would extend to you, Senator Stott Despoja, the invitation he extended to delegates at the conference—that is, he would encourage you to make your views known to the Privacy Commissioner.

BREAK.PARA: QUESTION ON NOTICE

(7) Have any pastoralists been assisted.

(9) (a) How many grants have been made to pastoralists and miners; (b) what are the names of each of these grantees; (e) which are indigenous and which are non‐indigenous.

(14) Has the Attorney‐General delegated all or any of his powers to the holder of an office in the Senior Executive Service of the Australian Public Service; if so: (a) to whom: and (b) what extent of those powers.
I am advised that the answers to the Honourable Senator's questions are as follows:

(2) 31 parties and/or groups have been granted assistance on one or more occasions since the enactment of the Act.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Guidelines for granting Financial Assistance by the Attorney‐General in Native Title Cases

BREAK.PARA: In certain circumstances, the Attorney‐General may provide financial assistance to people involved in native title cases under the Native Title Act 1993. The Attorney‐General may also provide financial assistance to respondents or plaintiffs in common law matters who are unable to obtain funding from elsewhere under a native title common law financial assistance scheme.
These guidelines apply to applications for financial assistance under both schemes.
Definitions
Under these guidelines, the following definitions apply:
a `party' is either an individual, company, partnership or trust that is involved directly in a native title matter;
an `applicant' is a party who is making a native title claim, otherwise known as a `claimant';
a `respondent' is a party who is opposing a claim; and
a `non‐claimant applicant' is a party who applies to the National Native Title Tribunal (NNTT) to make a native title determination.
The Grant of Assistance
Applications for financial assistance in native title matters will be decided by the Attorney‐General or someone who the Attorney‐General has authorised to make the decision for him or her.

A person applying for financial assistance will need to provide detailed information about the costs that they think they will have to pay and the reasons that they think each cost will be necessary. They will also need to give details of the way that the amount of each item has been calculated.
Any grant of assistance may be made either with or without conditions. If there are any conditions they will be described at the time that the grant is made.

Before the Attorney‐General will grant assistance a person must show that it will cause hardship to them if the application is not granted. They must also show that it is reasonable for a grant of assistance to be made to them. They must also be ineligible for financial assistance from any other source, such as a prescribed Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander representative body.
Hardship

Hardship means financial hardship. Hardship refers to whether the person applying for assistance is able to meet the cost of the case without getting into serious financial difficulty. In deciding whether refusing a grant will involve hardship to an applicant all relevant information is taken into account.

For this reason people applying for assistance will need to provide information about their income, expenditure, assets and liabilities and the amount that it is estimated the case will cost. When assessing a person's financial situation, the assets that are in dispute as a result of the native title claim will not be taken into account although these must be listed in the application.

If the person applying for assistance is a respondent in a test case the Attorney‐General also considers how important it is that the law that is being tested is made clearer by a decision of a court. A test case is a case where the Court is being asked to decide the meaning of an important question about some part of the Native Title Act or another Commonwealth law. For this reason much more importance is given to whether it is reasonable to grant assistance than is given to hardship.
The application for assistance must provide full details of the case including the question that will be answered by the Court and any other matters a Court decision will make clearer.
Reasonableness
To decide whether a grant of assistance is reasonable the Attorney‐General considers all of the following things:
(1) the prospects of success, which means
(a) for the applicant, whether or not they are likely to win the case
(b) for the respondent, whether they have a good case to argue
(c) for the non‐claimant applicant, whether it is necessary to have a native title determination made; and
(2) whether the benefit to the applicant or non‐claimant applicant is worth the cost of the case, or whether the respondent is likely to lose an interest in his/her land; and
(3) how much benefit the general public will gain from a decision in the case.
The Attorney‐General may ask for advice from other government agencies or industry bodies to help him or her decide whether it would be reasonable to grant the request for financial assistance.
Payment of costs
If the Attorney‐General decides to grant assistance he will only agree to pay costs that are reasonable and proper.

The person asking for assistance will need to nominate a lawyer to conduct the case. The lawyer chosen must be experienced in conducting cases in the Federal Court or a superior court of a State or Territory.

The amount of assistance granted will be either a percentage of reasonable professional costs (usually 80% of Federal Court Scale fees) or a lump sum fee that the Attorney‐General agrees will be paid. It is very important that your legal adviser understands what costs will be paid and the amount that will be paid for each item before he or she starts work.

The grant of assistance may be made in stages. Because costs for one stage of the case are paid this does not mean that all the costs will be paid. For example, a limited grant may be made to investigate the reasonableness of the case or a grant may be made for mediation only.

It may be a condition of the grant that the parties who are assisted by the Attorney‐General make some payment towards the cost of the case. This is called a contribution. Any contribution will be based on the party's ability to pay. If you have to make a contribution, the amount to be paid will be clear from the information that is given at the time that the grant is made.
You will always be asked to repay any amount that the Court awards to you as costs if you win.

All grants of assistance are monitored by the Attorney‐General who may ask for information from time to time. If this information is not provided the grant of aid may be suspended which means that any work that is done after the date it is suspended may not be paid for.
Applications for Assistance

If you are applying for assistance you should make sure that you have provided all the information that will be needed before the Attorney‐General can make a decision. Because of the strict timeframes under the Native Title Act it is essential that you include all relevant details in your application for assistance, as a decision may be based only on the information that is provided.
You should include:
a statement giving the reasons you have been refused assistance from another source, if any (ie a prescribed Aboriginal/Torres Strait Islander representative body);

a full financial statement including all assets, income from all sources, your expenses including loan repayments and living expenses and business expenses. You should list separately the assets that will be affected by the claim for native title;
full details of all costs including the way each cost has been calculated;
full details of the case, including the things that the Tribunal or Court will have to decide and, if it is a test case, why these are important;
a statement giving the reasons that you think you will win the case or the defences that you will argue, or if you are a non‐claimant applicant, why you need a determination made; and
the name and address of your solicitor, if you have one.
You will also need to provide a statement that the information you have provided in your application is true and correct.
If you want to apply for assistance or you would like more information you should write to:
The Director
Legal Aid and Family Services
Attorney‐General's Department

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate:

(a) recognises that today, 27 May 1997, is the 30th anniversary of the referendum that amended section 51(xxvi) of the Constitution, which gave the Commonwealth the power to make special laws for the people of any race, in particular Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people;
(b) reaffirms the support for the outcome of that referendum, which received the unprecedented support of 90.77 per cent of the Australian people;

(c) recognises the need for the legislative and other powers of the Commonwealth to be used to address the profound economic and social disadvantage continuing to be suffered by indigenous Australians—with specific emphasis on and practical measures to address health, housing, education and employment;

I am pleased, on behalf of the government, to move this motion in the Senate today. It is in identical terms to a motion being moved by the government in the other place. It gives parliamentarians an opportunity to reflect upon the significance of the 1967 referendum and what has been achieved since that date and also, as we put in the terms of the mo tion, to remind us of disadvantages still experienced by Aboriginal people and to pledge ourselves in the challenge to help overcome those disadvantages.

What happened some 30 years ago was that a referendum, sponsored by the then Holt government, granted the Commonwealth legislative power to make laws with respect to Aboriginal people. It also deleted the provisions of section 127 of the constitution which had prevented Aboriginal people from being counted in the national census. Section 51(xxvi) of the constitution originally permitted the Commonwealth parliament to make laws with respect to `the people of any race other than the Aboriginal race in any state for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws.' The words `other than the Aboriginal race in any state' were removed in 1967, thereby allowing the Commonwealth to pass specific laws relating to our indigenous people. This of course had previously been within the legislative responsibility of the states.
In addition, as I said, the 1967 referendum repealed section 127 of the constitution, which read:
In reckoning the numbers of the people of the Commonwealth or of a state or other part of the Commonwealth, Aboriginal natives shall not be counted.

Indigenous people have of course been counted in each census since the removal of section 127. The 27th of May 1967 therefore is a very important date in the history of Australia. It was one of the major steps upon the long road of achieving true equality for indigenous people.

There had of course been other significant steps, such as the granting of citizenship in 1948 and the granting of the vote in 1962, but what I guess was special about the 1967 referendum was that it was the only time that the Australian people as a whole had the opportunity to directly express their views. The fact that an overwhelming majority—as I said, some 90.77 per cent—voted for the change demonstrated the extent to which Australians as a whole realised that injustice and inequality for Aboriginal Australians had to be addressed.

BREAK.PARA: It was also an important referendum because, although it may have been led by the Liberal‐National government, it was supported by all sides of the parliament. In fact, as I understand it, there was no case put to voters. We would like to think that the 1967 referendum was symbolic of the Australian people's fair‐mindedness, tolerance and goodwill to build a shared future for all Australians within our country.

It recognised, we believed, that there was a need to address the profound economic and social disadvantages suffered by indigenous people.

In the following 30 years, there have been many changes and many attempts by this parliament and other parliaments to address those disadvantages and injustices. Whereas there is obviously room to debate the effectiveness of those attempts—and there has not always been cross‐party support for the details of the reforms that have been instituted—nevertheless I think it is fair to say that there has been unanimity in the view that efforts should be made to overcome the injustices of the past and to move towards true equality.

We could look at reforms such as the establishment of the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the development of a dedicated legal and health service for Aboriginal people, the establishment of a federal portfolio devoted to indigenous Australians, the development of the community employment development program, the community housing and infrastructure program for indigenous peoples, the community infrastructure priority projects scheme, the further development of Aboriginal health services and national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy. And we could continue. We could speak of the purpose and goals of the establishment of ATSIC, all leading to an attempt to find reconciliation through the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation which was established in 1991. Most of those more recent initiatives were initiatives of Labor governments in this place, but if I go back a little further we will recollect the decision of the Fraser government in 1976 to grant land rights to Aboriginal people in the Northern Territory.

On top of this, we have legislation protecting Aboriginal heritage sites. It can and will be further improved. In question time today Senator Alston drew attention to the role that has been played in the protection and promotion of indigenous art and culture and the benefits that can flow to Aboriginal people from a wider acknowledgment and appreciation of those arts and culture.

We come up to more contemporary times through this experience, recognising what has been achieved and also what has not yet been achieved, to the process of reconciliation which, I guess, in many ways, is an attempt to address the spiritual differences of the past and to draw Australians closer together, to recognise history and the consequences of history, but to particularly look forward and to recognise, as the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said yesterday in Melbourne, that a vital part of reconciliation must be working together `to raise the living standards and broaden opportunities available to the most disadvantaged group in Australian society' of the Australian indigenous people. That is why, obviously, we strongly support the reconciliation process.

In recent times we have had to address the challenges presented by the High Court in its Mabo judgment. Even then, I think that all parties in this place accept native title. There have been differences in how you provide an administrative framework for it but all parties have accepted in good spirit the right to native title. We have seen the parliament in this place wrestle with the tragedy of deaths in custody and I think we still, unfortunately, have not found the full and adequate answers to that situation. Now the latest chapter, as we move down this path of reconciliation, is to provide an appropriate response to the report on separation of children, a report which has been acknowledged by the coalition government to recognise a regrettable part of Australia's history, certainly not a part that was recognised at the time to be regrettable.

In fact, generally the policies of that time were pursued in a way that they believed was to the benefit of Aboriginal children. Now, of course, with the benefit of hindsight we realise that in many ways they were very cruel policies that took from these children their identity, their family, their culture and their traditions. Having learnt from the experiences of the past, our challenge is now to find an appropriate way in which to address that recognition as well.

It has been a difficult path. We do not underestimate the challenges that still lie ahead, but we do take this opportunity to commit ourselves to achieving justice for indigenous people to overcome the disadvantages they have suffered in the past and still continue to suffer, to overcome disadvantages in the areas of health, education, housing and particularly job opportunities, and in particular to encourage respect for indigenous people, their traditions, culture and their most important place within our broader community.
