South Australian women and Aborigines had the right to vote before Federation but the Commonwealth Franchise Act 1902, whilst extending the right to vote to women for federal elections, explicitly disenfranchised Aborigines.

In a similar vein, the Invalid and Old Age Pensions Act 1908 disqualified Aborigines from receiving the pension. This racism by omission and commission occurred against a background of state government policies of assimilation that ignored and devalued Aboriginal culture, shattered Aboriginal families and communities, and continued the dispos session and alienation of Aboriginal people from their land. The fact that we joined other democracies in 1939 to fight against forces committed to notions of racial superiority and to active policies of genocide appears to have made little immediate connection to the conduct of domestic policies.

Isolated but articulate voices began to be heard in this Commonwealth parliament. In 1950, moved by appalling circumstances of both remote Aboriginal communities and fringe dwellers, Paul Hasluck called for federal intervention in both policy and funding in Aboriginal affairs. He even succeeded in having a motion unanimously supported in the House of Representatives, but official government policy remained inert.

The minerals boom from the 1950s and through the 1960s and 1970s saw increasing pressure on Aboriginal communities where the people had been until then able to pursue a traditional lifestyle. The impact of the miners was largely unwelcome.

In 1957 Gordon Bryant used the evidence of the negative impact of minerals development to propose to the parliament that `power to control native affairs should reside in this parliament'. Gough Whitlam and Kim Beazley Snr called for a wider Commonwealth role. In 1963 they were parties to presenting to the government the petition of the Yolngu people of Yirrkala protesting against mining leases in Arnhem Land.

But Australian developments were not occurring in isolation. Anti-racist, anti-colonialist sentiments found voice across the world, in freedom marches in the United States, in the resolutions of the United Nations and in the emerging widespread criticism of apartheid in South Africa.

The coming of the television age and the greater mobility of Australian people saw their knowledge and experience of the real circumstances of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people greatly enhanced. I think the ABC in general and their current affairs programs such as Four Corners and This Day Tonight played an honourable and significant role in raising public awareness.

The Federal Council for the Advancement of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders campaigned throughout the 1960s across a broad front for justice and equity for indigenous peoples, and was at the forefront of the campaign that ultimately brought us the 1967 referendum. Its activities were mirrored by state‐based equivalent organisations and it was supported by religious groups such as the Society of Friends, which rejected the older paternalistic models in working with indigenous people.

The television and other media exposed Australians to positive images of black leader ship. Heroes in other places, such as Martin Luther King Junior and Nelson Mandela, had their Australian counterparts in people such as Faith Bandler. When the freedom rides of America's deep south were emulated in Australia, we saw the emergence of Charles Perkins. In the same year, Billy Wentworth, Gordon Bryant and Kim Beazley Senior sought to amend government proposals for constitutional amendment by including a new section 51(xxvi) proscribing racial discrimination. The bill was passed, but lapsed.

It was these worthy campaigners, together with Gough Whitlam, who were at the forefront of the renewed efforts in the parliament in 1967. State leaders such as Don Dunstan ran vigorous yes campaigns. There was no doubt in the minds of the campaigners that the amendment to section 51 was enacted to enable the betterment of indigenous people. An editorial in the West Australian of the day remarked:
The government has been given a firm directive to go far beyond its past efforts.
The then Deputy Leader of the Country Party, Doug Anthony, said:
This would give the Commonwealth, for the first time, power to make special laws for the benefit of Aboriginal people throughout Australia.

Real Commonwealth initiatives in response to the new constitutional power dated from 1972. Legislation such as the Aboriginal Loans Commission Act 1974, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander (Queensland Discriminatory Laws) Act 1975, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, and all subsequent exercises of the power, have had a common factor. They were all for the betterment of indigenous people. There has never been a suggestion that the power could be the basis for undermining or diminishing the common law or statutory rights of Aborigines or Torres Strait Islanders.

The Racial Discrimination Act 1975, introduced by the Whitlam government and supported by the Fraser‐Anthony opposition, married the new power with the existing external affairs power to give force to our international treaty obligations to address racial discrimination. The thrust of initiatives from 1967 onwards has been for the improve ment of the health, education and general wellbeing of indigenous people. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 was the culmination of a move away from paternalism and welfare mentality towards greater empowerment and self‐determination.

The Native Title Act 1993 enables indigenous people to access an alternative and less adversarial means of proving title on lands where native title has yet to be extinguished by later grants or land use in the post‐colonial era. It would be a travesty and a tragedy if the government were to use a constitutional power enacted for the betterment of indigenous people to attempt to amend the act in a way that seeks to wind back their existing statutory or common law rights. We believe that it would not only be wrong, but ultimately would be shown to be illegal, albeit after costly and socially divisive litigation and public outcry.

Commonwealth action following the 1967 referendum has seen significant advances in education for indigenous people. The influence and achievement of indigenous leaders today is testimony to the advances in participation in secondary and further education. Increasing representation of indigenous people across the professions—in academia, the arts and public administration—is the cause of community pride.

There is still much to be achieved in indigenous health, in reducing imprisonment rates, in addressing Aboriginal deaths in custody and in healing the personal and social wounds that are the legacy of generations of neglect and active dispossession. Just as surely as the referendum was an event of significance, so is the release this week of the report of the National Inquiry into the Separation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Children from Their Families. This is a matter that will be dealt with later this week in the Senate, but it is appropriate to reflect on it in the context of the motion that is before the Senate today.

The significance of the report will be amplified and will be defined by the way in which the government and the parliament respond to it. If we fail to apologise for the pain, suffering and social dislocation documented in the report, and if we fail to respond with ample compensation and restitution to the survivors and their families, we will have lost an historic opportunity and we will have gravely damaged the cause of reconciliation. We cannot rewrite history but we can shape the future.

The 1967 referendum conferred on the Commonwealth a specific responsibility. A part of that responsibility is to protect our minorities. The nature of parliamentary democracy is such that the majority obviously will determine the government of the day. It is for that government to protect the culture, the beliefs and the wellbeing of minorities who could be sidelined in the process. Reconciliation for all Australians requires us to respect the rights of all Australians.

I commend the amendment I have moved to the government's motion. It is the same as an amendment that will be moved in the House of Representatives by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley. We must not put at risk the real progress that we have made since 1967. Let us properly commemorate the success of the referendum, and let us move together towards 2000, united, peaceful and justly proud of a shared rich heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) to speak to this motion. I note that the reason she is not here today is because she is at the Australian Reconciliation Convention which she regards as being a very important step and an important place to be at this time. In her place, I speak on behalf of the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I want to say is that it gives me no pleasure to discover that a motion which has been moved by the opposition has, at this late stage, been amended by the government, and the government's amendments propose something much weaker than what was proposed by the opposition—which the Democrats certainly support. So I want to support the amendment moved by Senator Faulkner which put the critical words back in this motion.

BREAK.PARA: We do not want this kind of shallow tipping of the hat. I do not know what words to use, because I am fairly angry that this government did not itself propose any motion until the opposition shamed it into proposing something. Then it tried to water down and weaken absolutely what the opposition had proposed. It seems to me that, if the government—in the spirit of reconciliation—wanted to support the kind of motion the opposition was moving, it would have done so in a spirit of cooperation rather than trying to destroy the original motion.

No matter what words the government proposes, there are some critical phrases in its proposal which to me are a denial of what we ought to be doing here today. Let me point out a couple of these things. What the government is trying to do is to support the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who in his speech yesterday tried to drive a wedge between what he calls practical measures—which he supports—and mere symbolism. I want to say to the Prime Minister that there is no choice between symbolism and practical measures. Both are important and, if we are really fair dinkum about reconciliation and about acknowledging our own history—not just 200 years of history but our own history of yesterday, last month, last year and this year—both must be put in this place.

There is no reconciliation without justice, and symbolism is as important as practical measures. The referendum in 1967 gave the Commonwealth government the power to make laws for the benefit of Aboriginals and Islanders. It was at that point in history that the recognition was made that state governments had failed miserably to deliver justice and that, finally, the Commonwealth government would have to step in and make those laws on behalf of us all.

In relationships, symbolism is sometimes even more important than practical measures—or at least ought to precede the practical measures. In relationships between individual people and between groups of people, it is important to say sorry for the wrongs not just of the distant past but of the immediate past, so that forgiveness can be offered and reconciliation can then take place and be followed by the practical measures which all of us agree are absolutely fundamental and important. But it is no use the government trying to say, `We will take practical measures', and then in a mealy‐mouthed way saying that the symbolism of apologies and the rest is not important. It is.

The other part of the government's proposal which makes me very angry is the change from placing the plaque in the new Parliament House to putting it into a backroom in the old Parliament House. This is symbolic of what this government has tried to do with this issue all along. It keeps on saying, `This is a matter of history. We cannot take the blame for what happened 200 years ago.' We cannot, but we can take the blame for what we ourselves have done and for what our parliaments have done in the last 30 years. In my own lifetime—and the lifetime of most people in this place—I am aware of appalling behaviour on the part of parliaments of various political colours in Queensland. We may not be personally responsible for what happened 200 years ago, but we are responsible for our own generation and for what we allowed to happen yesterday, the day before, the month before that and last year. We are responsible for what happens this year.

The Democrats reject utterly the attempt by the government to water down this motion. We certainly support what the opposition is doing in seeking to restore the words which have been omitted. I hope the government in its shame will reconsider what it is trying to do and will support the original motion and the amendments to make that original motion the motion before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell, Sen Ronald

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, 27 May, is the 30th anniversary of the 1967 referendum that amended the Australian constitution and gave recognition to the indigenous people of Australia—the first Australians. I cannot for the life of me understand why it took until 1967. It was well within my time: I can remember the day; I can even remember going down to vote. It was a significant advancement for Australia, and one that came far too late. When Australians were given the opportunity to recognise the indigenous people—the first Australians—an overwhelming majority of 90 per cent or 93 per cent, or whatever it was, took the opportunity to recognise Australian Aboriginals and have them recognised under the federal constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that, if a referendum was put forward today, it would be carried by an even greater majority. I do not think there is any fair‐minded Australian who would not wish to see all indigenous people have this recognition under the Australian constitution. I also recognise that there would be very few Australians who would not want indigenous people to have equal access to good health facilities, education and other opportunities. All Australians would want equal opportunities for Aboriginals to advance their quality of life.

We have got to give a hand up to all sorts of people when they are disadvantaged, whether they be Aboriginals, people who are in droughts or people affected by low commodity prices. Despite the Hanson rhetoric, which is only a vocal minority, there really exists in all Australians a heartfelt belief for a fair go for everyone and an intense dislike of racism. This would culminate in support for a similar referendum, which would be as overwhelming today as it was in 1967.

Australia has made great steps forward since 1967. We have seen Aboriginal and Islander leaders proudly and effectively representing and speaking for their communities through their elected bodies. There are achievements in all walks of life—in law, medicine. I know one Islander who recently became a doctor. There have been magnificent achievements in the arts, reflecting the beauty and pride felt in indigenous culture. There has also been widespread international recognition of indigenous arts and crafts, music and dance. There has been international recognition of these great gifts and they have attracted and promoted tourism to Australia.

Today, through education and understanding, there exists widespread awareness and recognition within the community of the great wealth and history of indigenous people. Australian people are rightly focusing on the existing health, education, housing and sanitation facilities that are still badly needed in some communities and are concentrating on the programs required to address these problems. I recognise Senator Woodley's commitment to the Aboriginal community and his impassioned speech a few minutes ago. But I do think we have got to put our best efforts where they are required the most.

I have been fortunate. I have travelled throughout Queensland and other states, and I have been honoured to share the indigenous culture of the Aboriginals and Islander people from the Torres Strait and to see the advancement over the years in Queensland where there has been a deed of grant, where millions and millions of acres of land—I think it is 200 million acres or something of that nature—were given as a deed of grant to indigenous communities. It is not just wasteland. It is beautiful coastal productive land up and down the Gulf of Carpentaria.

I regret in recent months that the Wik debate has created division and rancour that was not there in the immediate past. There was a good working relationship—probably the only working relationship in Australia—where indigenous people and pastoralists worked together and recognised each other's abilities. Race relations have regressed and have been put back as a result of the High Court decision on Wik, and Noel Pearson—whom I admire as a leader of his community—and I are now on opposite sides of a debate. We are both standing up for different principles, and that should not make enemies out of us—or enemies out of the graziers or the Aboriginals in rural communities. What we should be trying to achieve is a better relationship between Australians and Aboriginals. I hope that this Wik debate disappears into the ether in the future and it all goes back to the way it was.

I acknowledge the injustices done by past policies that were blatantly wrong. These were policies that were made in a different time and in different circumstances—in earlier times where the ethos was totally different from that we have now. Injustices were done resulting in longstanding hurt and deprivation.

BREAK.PARA: But looking over your shoulder never really gets you a long way. Looking backwards does not solve the problems of today or tomorrow. I am personally prepared to say that I am sorry and that I regret the actions of the past. I regret that the injustices of the past happened. If we could wind the clock back I am sure that they would never happen again.

The focus now must be on the future and letting indigenous people look after their own affairs. I have had a little to do with indigenous people. I certainly do not proclaim that I am an expert, but if you have indigenous people in communities who are prepared to go out and do their own thing I would plead that they be allowed to—not that white advisers be allowed in there. I am not being derogatory about the intentions of white advisers but I think it is time that these people were allowed to make their own way in life. If they make mistakes, they will correct them. But let them do it themselves.

Cooperation must come from all well‐meaning Australians to endorse and continue their support for the sentiments expressed by the 1967 referendum and from indigenous Australians with the guiding influence of their culture and aspirations. I support the motion today. I recognise it as symbolising a significant day of advancement of relationships between all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to support the amendments moved by Senator Faulkner. In doing so I speak with a combination of anger and sorrow. I feel the injustice of a continuation of government policy. I feel the frustration of a process which does not treat indigenous Australians with respect. I feel anger and sorrow because I can see rights long fought for being taken away or there being an attempt to take them away. I feel anger and sorrow about a Prime Minister and government who refuse to embrace indigenous Australians as equals and who do not understand the importance of doing so. I feel this because I can see that Australia is being subjected to divisive debate. I feel this anger and sorrow because Australian society is worse off because of a lack of leadership on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). And I feel it because many Australians are being vilified for no other reason than the colour of their skin.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a major difference between the opposition's motion—the one I gave notice of yesterday and which was moved today by Senator Faulkner—and that of the government. For us, this is a historic opportunity to embrace the principles and the spirit of the 1967 referendum, and to recognise its historic importance and its relevance to Australians now—to our cohesiveness, to our identity, to our sense of self‐dignity, to our image in the world and to our role in the world. It is a chance for this Senate to lay down the boundaries for the future by embracing an important aspect of the past. It is a chance to say, `Yes, we have moved on. We are on the road to implementing the impact and the spirit of the referendum. We are in the business of discharging our responsibilities and we will continue to pursue the principles of that referendum.'

That referendum was all about one thing: the dignity of human beings. It was about respect for religion, for culture and for equality. It goes to the heart of what civilisation is about—the question of human dignity. It was important in both effect and symbolism. It was a belated embrace by non‐indigenous Australians of indigenes as equals. They were not recognised at constitutional conventions. In fact, only one New Zealander spoke of indigenous Australians in those conventions some 100 years ago. To the effect that they were recognised in the constitution, they were recognised in two negative concepts: section 51(xxvi) excluded the Aboriginal race from Commonwealth legislative power to make laws with respect to the people of any race and section 127 ensured that Aboriginals were not included as people for electoral purposes.
The Governor‐General today, speaking in Melbourne, made the telling and relevant point about what happened at those constitutional conventions. He said:
Not surprisingly, the section—
he was talking about section 127—

BREAK.PARA: came increasingly to be seen as a constitutional declaration of the essential worthlessness and irrelevance of Australia's indigenous peoples. 1967 was all about redressing that.

The referendum played an important role then and it laid the foundation for much of the future. Reconciliation and the question of separation of families, native title and all those concepts flow from the responsibility of the federal government to act in the interests of indigenous Australians. It should continue to play a redemptive role for the past racism that we had to purge then and that we continue to have to purge now in the context of current debates. It was a referendum which laid the foundations, the ground rules, for the future and the benchmark for future action—action which was quite well reinforced in 1975 by the implementation of the Racial Discrimination Act by the Whitlam government.

Those foundations are still being tested in this place as we grapple with not just the issues of the welfare of Aboriginal Australians but also the fundamental issues of their right to the land and questions relating to the Wik decision and native title. They got rights in 1967 but, more importantly, symbolically and powerfully, they got a right to be treated as equals. What that referendum said to the Australian parliament was that those rights needed to be delivered upon. We are talking about more than physical rights. It was an expectation and an entitlement to be treated with dignity as human beings—the concept of respect for spirituality and culture.

In yesterday's Melbourne Age, Galarrwuy Yunupingu made it clear that the rights Aboriginal Australians want and deserve are more than just the tangible physical rights this government wants to focus on. He says:
Without our rights to land, we will be like a dry leaf dropped from a tree, floating down the river with no direction, no home and no future.
Mr Howard wants to cut us off from our roots and leave us like parasites around the edges of the cities and towns of Australia, living on compensation payments, grieving for our land.
He went on to say:
Native title is not a piece of paper or words in a book. It is our living Aboriginal culture. It is our songs and our dances, painted on our bodies and written in the sand.
And further:
Our children should be able to grow up equal, as mates, in a fair country. Killing off our law and culture will make this impossible.

So it is important for us to recognise more than what this government wants to recognise. It is important for us to recognise that equality means recognition of the spirit as well as the body. As Governor-General Deane said today, we have to address the problems of the spirit as well as those of the body.

That referendum did not just happen. It built up over a number of years. A whole body of people were involved in it, from Aboriginal Australians to hundreds of thousands of non-Aboriginal Australians. There were the freedom fighters of the 1960s. Vincent Lingiari led a walk off for 10 years of the Gurindji workers of Wave Hill in 1966. There was a coalition of Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians in 1967 involving a whole raft of people, including the political leaders. I am glad to say that the leadership from our side of politics came from Gough Whitlam, Don Dunstan and Kim Beazley Snr. But that leadership did not just come from our side—and I will go to that in a few moments—because Prime Minister Holt and the then Deputy Leader of the Country Party, Doug Anthony, were also instrumental at the time.

What the Labor Party is asking the Senate to do today is to live up to the standards of that referendum. But, unfortunately, this government cannot bring itself up to the barrier, and it is for that reason that we have moved our amendment. We see the government's motion as being weasel words of little impact and no effect.

I am sorry to say that, in moving what they have moved today—in being pushed into it by the Labor Party and now of course by the rest of the Senate—they have once again failed Australia. We have tried to negotiate. We were met with insensitivity. We were met with stubbornness. We were met with the normal response from the Prime Minister— that is, `Oh, that is politically correct. I won't have a bar of it.' Equal rights is more than political correctness. As I said, it goes to the heart of civilisation.

We have problems with the government's motion. First of all, it condones an abuse of the race power. Our motions—the one I moved yesterday and the amendment moved today by Senator Faulkner—make it very clear in clause (3) and clause (6) that we expect this parliament to live up to the letter and the spirit of the referendum. That is, the race power as amended in 1967 can only be used for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I stress that: it is for their benefit. As we say in clause (6), the Senate:
. . . calls upon all Australian governments and Parliaments, and all Australians, to respect and honour both the letter and spirit of the 1967 referendum—

The question is this: can you use the power entrusted to the parliament in 1967 to act in a way discriminatory against Aboriginal Australians? We say you cannot. The whole reason the constitution was changed then was to empower the government to overcome some of the problems of discrimination against indigenous Australians.

By attempting to delete that, the government gives a very clear signal. That signal is that they are prepared to attempt to use this power to discriminate against Aboriginal Australians. It is an abuse of the power entrusted to us and, for that reason, we are proceeding with clauses (3) and (6) of our amendment. We have to live up to the letter of that referendum.
We also have to live up to the promises and commitments made on all sides of parliament. Prime Minister Harold Holt said at the time in supporting the referendum:

We cannot allow it to be said that our constitution discriminates against some people who live within our shores—the Aborigines. Nor is it, we believe, acceptable to the Australian people that the national parliament should not have the power to make special laws for the people of the Aboriginal race where that is in their best interests.
Doug Anthony, the Deputy Leader of the Country Party, said:

. . . words which can be read as discriminating against the Aboriginal race will be removed. This would give the Commonwealth, for the first time, power to make special laws for the benefit of Aboriginal people throughout Australia.
Gough Whitlam, the Leader of the Labor Party, said:

The welfare of Australian Aboriginals requires this referendum be carried. The good name of Australia demands it be carried overwhelmingly. The Commonwealth must now be empowered to accept that responsibility on behalf of Aboriginals, as it already does for all other Australians.

There was no question at the time of what the leadership was on about. It was changing the constitution to empower the government to overcome the problems of indigenous Australians and to act in their interest. If anyone had any doubt, Governor-General Deane once again today made it clear when talking about the pre‐existing 1967 situation. He said:

That meant that, while the exclusion remained, the Commonwealth lacked legislative power to make any law designed for the special benefit of the Aboriginal people in any of the states. In contrast, once the exclusion was deleted, the Commonwealth, under section 51(xxxvi), possessed plenary legislative power to make any special laws which it deemed necessary for the welfare of the Aboriginal peoples.

Why is the government running away from such an explicit understanding of what is in the referendum? They know they cannot use the foreign affairs power to take away Aboriginal rights to title. They are signalling here that they want to use the race power and they want to rewrite history to do so—for instance, in the immediate future with their 10‐point plan. They want the right to introduce and pass legislation which discriminates against Aboriginal Australians. Would you believe it? On the 30th anniversary of this referendum, they want the power to be able to introduce racist legislation, and we will not have a bar of it.

As to the second part of our concern, I will digress for a moment and go to clause (7). We feel it is relevant now to continue to commemorate the 1967 referendum and to have the plaque which was unveiled today by the Governor‐General and Dr Faith Bandler properly housed within this parliament.

The referendum is of relevance now. It is not a past event of no relevance and with no impact on our future. That referendum should guide us by its presence, and we should not consign it to a rickety old museum. We need to treat Aboriginal rights as equal and we should not put it in Old Parliament House.

Nothing could better symbolise this government's attitude. They are saying, `Yes, we acknowledged your existence in 1967, but we are not going to acknowledge your place in the modern nation as we move into the next millennium.' They are saying, `Rather than having a place in the living heart of our democracy, your referendum can sit in a museum like the skeletal remains of some long dead ancestor.' We will not have a bar of that.
It is quite amazing that the government wants to change the motion we moved yesterday to remove the reference to:

. . . health, housing, education, employment and related measures, but also through measures to redress, to the extent now possible, the deprivation of life, liberty, property and dignity which indigenous people have suffered through so much of Australia's history;
They cannot deny it happened. Why do they want to write it out of history now? They also want to remove the words from our motion that says that the Senate:
. . . recognises the critical importance to indigenous Australians and the wider Australian community of a continuing reconciliation process—
God, you reckon we need it—
based on understanding of and frank apologies for what has gone wrong in the past, and total commitment to equal respect in the future;
It is not hard to say sorry, and it is something that we should be saying in this place. The reconciliation process needs to continue and it needs to be embodied here.

You have to ask yourself of the Prime Minister: why can he not do the decent thing? Why can he not apologise? Why can he not respond to the public opinion polls this time? Sixty-five per cent of Australians say that we need to have an official acknowledgment and apology for the separation of Aboriginal children. He did respond to those polls in every other instance but he cannot bring himself around to do it in power.

Why can the Prime Minister not call the dark spots in our history for what they are? Why does he always have to divert to some general parenthood words about our history? We have had some dark spots. Why does he not condemn them as leader of this nation? Why can he not agree with Holt and Anthony? Why does he repudiate the Liberal Party history? When you look at them all—Holt, Anthony, Hewson, Fraser and McMahon—this bloke is not the most conservative Liberal Party leader in history, as he claims to be; but he is the most prejudiced.

In the few minutes left to me I want say a few words about the people who have been running a very strong leadership role in opposition to this Prime Minister and his lack of leadership. These people are concerned that we do not fall into the trap of entrenching division, suspicion and hatred based on race, as I think the direct impact of the government's policies are bringing about. I refer to the black leaders. They are not the sources of the problem; in fact, I know from the contact I have had with them that they are sincere, intelligent and committed, and they show leadership and they are prepared to negotiate.

I saw Pat Dodson on TV last night. I must say that he epitomised what modern black leadership is about. He was restrained and he handled the chairing of the reconciliation process extremely well. He is a measured man. His words yesterday—he said that if we cannot achieve coexistence, we cannot achieve reconciliation—were words that the government should listen too.

I know that Mick Dodson feels Australian from time to time. He is an intelligent and powerful man. Lois O'Donoghue is a person who was separated from her mother. If anyone really wants to hear about the impact of separation, have a talk to Lois some day. There are more, including Noel Pearson. I will just mention the ones that I have had contact with. They include Tracker Tilmouth, Marcia Langton, Galarrwuy and Mandawuy Yunupingu, Peter Yu, Charlie Perkins, Sugar Ray Robinson and now Gatjil Djerrkura. I am sure I have missed a lot out. They are people who have actually shown a lot of leadership, are measured in their approach and are quite scientific and forensic in their assessment of issues.

I also wish to say something about Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner Wilson, with whom I have had tussles from time to time in government. He made the telling point yesterday that truth is the only foundation for reconciliation. The work that he has done in recent years, particularly on this issue and on others, is something that needs to be recognised in this parliament. The fact that he was subjected to government besmirching and attacking his reputation because of this separation report is something that I think no government should be proud of.

In closing, this is not an issue that will go away. Until we reconcile with our indigenous Australians, we will not be comfortable and relaxed. Until we live with, enjoy and cherish our diversity, we will not have matured as a nation. Until we coexist properly, earnestly and frankly, we will not be able to walk together into the future.

It is not too late to call on the government now, and to call on Senator Hill in particular, to do the decent thing. Your Prime Minister is wrong. The Prime Minister lives under his shield of prejudice. The Prime Minister is proud of the fact that he is more conservative than every other Liberal Party leader in history. He is wrong. I think it is important for senators here on the other side to tell him so and to embrace the opposition's motion.

—Senator Margetts, I do not know whether you are reflecting on my inability to give you the call, but the agreement was that Senator Woodley was speaking on behalf of Senator Kernot, then Senator Boswell, and Senator Bolkus was seconding that motion, as I understand it. —I guess the instructions perhaps should have been revised to look at some justice and representation, which is perhaps the very thing we are talking about here. In the last few weeks it was prepared to let electoral expediency overrule the right of people to be heard in respect of justice.

We have heard from Senator Boswell that race relations have been put back as a result of the High Court decision on Wik. No, race relations were not put back as a result of the High Court decision on Wik. Race relations were put back because people believed and still believe that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be seen. They may be allowed to be seen—perhaps not everywhere—but not heard. When Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people seek to be heard, then that is considered to be inappropriate.

So we have had a call for silence. We continue to have people told, `If only you didn't say that', `If only you didn't do that,' `If only black activists didn't open their mouths.' We still have in our country an overwhelming paternalism, and paternalism does equal racism. We heard the words from the late Prime Minister Holt, `laws in their best interests.' Yes, the system was set up with a sense of paternalism and it has con tinued that way. We still have a situation whereby it was considered, when the Native Title Bill was passed, that this parliament gave rights to Aboriginal people. No, this parliament did not. Those rights exist. Those rights have always existed. However, the High Court very belatedly recognised those rights, but only a little bit.

This parliament, if anything, took away some of those rights and reassured other people of their rights. The decision in relation to Wik was considered to be a concern because for some reason there might be a recognition that Aboriginal people still existed on pastoral land—still existed or were allowed to exist, or were allowed to have some basis for existing on pastoral land. What do people expect them to do? They cannot go away. They cannot repudiate their connections to the land.

Within these statements we see the word `disadvantages'—for that read `discrimination.' If we do not see that word as `discrimination', we will continue to see the parliament and white society as being the paternalistic giver of benefits, not as the people who will eventually allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to make decisions for themselves. Is this so scary, that people will have rights of self‐determination?

The perceptions of the Native Title Act were widely advertised. Many people felt that justice was being delivered. Many other people knew it was not. Having run by that false perception, which I have to say the then government inspired, it was then easy to assume that something was given and therefore something could be taken away. The reality is that nothing was given. However, that is not stopping this current government from wanting to take something more away.

This proves without any doubt in my mind the fragility of the concept of social justice within our current parliamentary system. It proves to me that Australia cannot pretend to be a just society until, within our constitution, there are words that guarantee the basic rights of citizens and, in particular, there are words that guarantee basic human rights to our indigenous people. That is well overdue.

I believe that we cannot continue as a society to hold our head up in any international arena until we redress these issues; until we redress the wrongs not just of the past but also the wrongs of the present. We must deal with the false perceptions. We must not feed on the fear and uncertainty of our economic times. We must, first of all, be honest about what is causing the problems in our society, what is causing the uncertainty in our society, deal with those honestly, and not rely on the scapegoat easy way out of blaming those groups in our society who have less power.

What is happening in our society is that we are making ourselves feel better by blaming someone else. The now opposition gave the perception of giving something to Aboriginal people when in fact it was giving as much certainty as it could to all other property interests in Australia. We must be willing to see that there are people who would feed on that uncertainty in our society by attempting to even erode the few rights that exist.

I will be supporting the ALP's amendment to the government's motion, but I do not support the view that that gives the opposition the right to feel complacent and the right to feel that their words excuse them for their recent actions—not just their actions in relation to Hindmarsh but also their actions in relation to the way in which the Native Title Bill was negotiated. Many people were disenfranchised during that process. The legislation was pushed as giving rights to Aboriginal people, which it did not. This paternalistic lie has continued to be put. We will not advance until that lie is redressed and admitted. It seems that we will continue to go backwards in times of continued uncertainty until there are constitutional rights guaranteed for all Australians but, in particular, for indigenous Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments put by the Labor Party. They are a real effort to put some body back into this motion—to get past blandishments and carefully worded generalities and to try to be specific about addressing the problems of the past, and to bring real reconciliation into a united Australian approach to the future.

SPEECH.PARA: There is more than a passing connection between this internal affair for Australia and the face we present to the rest of the world by how we address our internal shortcomings, as far as the history of relations with the indigenous Australian population is concerned, and the way in which today a Chinese senior minister, Zhu Rongji, fifth ranking Minister for Economics, is being hosted by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), in what I see as a trade in silence. Today outside this parliament the Tibetan flags are flying alongside the representations of the Aboriginal people still seeking justice in this country. What we can see afoot in the refusal of the Australian government to openly address the litany of wrongs being visited on the indigenous people of Tibet is silence from the Chinese authorities about what happens here in Australia as far as the indigenous people of this country are concerned.

There is more than trade in commodities on the agenda in those talks in the Prime Minister's suite today. There is a trade in silence, and it is a trade in dishonourable silence: if China goes quiet on what is happening in this country, we will go quiet on what is happening in Tibet. We cannot escape that conclusion. We cannot escape the fact that in both countries the appalling circumstances that have in the past visited the indigenous people of the world, and which continue to afflict some 300 million indigenous people around the world, are being continued because their interests will be seen as getting in the way of the interests of the rich and the powerful around the world, the people who have the power as against the people who do not.

I cannot pass up altogether the remarks of the Leader of the National Party (Senator Boswell) in this chamber because, while I accept the sincerity of what he had to say, there is echoing in his words what is wrong with the approach of not a few Australians, and particularly people on the right of the political spectrum in this country, in terms of their concern to allay any difficulties that may be seen in the relationship between indigenous Australians and the rest of Australia, and any obligations that may have to be met by the government of the day, of which they are part.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Boswell said, `I hope the Wik debate disappears into the ether and it all goes back to where it was.' There is implicit in those words a placing of responsibility, if you like, on the Aboriginal people for the controversy that has arisen as a result of the Wik decision. I submit that the boot is on the other foot. The Wik decision was a very short footstep, where a long footstep is needed, towards redressing the rights of Aboriginal and indigenous people to their land, so long taken away from them.

As I see it, the wish that everything would go back to where it was is simply a means of inherently blaming those people who are raising a controversy, as if the controversy itself ought not to exist. But, as previous speakers on this side of the parliament have said, the controversy will not go away until we address it and until we fix it, and the responsibility for that controversy is on our shoulders, not on the shoulders of the Aboriginal and indigenous Australian people.

Senator Boswell said, `It is time now these people were allowed to make their own way in life, free of white advisers.' There is a penetrating paternalism about those words. It is as if access to advice—white, black or whatever—in this country ought to be a prerogative of those of us who have the money, the links and the power. Let us remember that we are in a system where the law is based on the protection of property and where the law is more readily accessible and usable to their advantage by the people who have the property, by the people who have the money, by the people who can afford the counsel.

How dare we reflect on those people who are at the other end of the spectrum—dispossessed, their law set aside, having the option only of recourse to the law imposed on them—by saying that they should not have access to the advice that the rest of us have. I do not believe Senator Boswell means to be discriminatory in what he says. I believe he is simply reflecting the inability to empathise with the indigenous people, try as he might, that so many other Australians who are unable to grasp the need for reconciliation have, and which blights their ability to feel strongly about the need for this nation to grasp this problem and correct it in so far as we can.

Finally, Senator Boswell, representing the National Party, said, `Millions and millions of acres of land were given as a deed of grant to the Aboriginal people in Queensland, in the Gulf of Carpentaria region.' Again, those words give away the problem which is ours in redressing the wrongs of the past.

How can we say it was big of us to give land to people which was theirs at the outset? Are we not saying, in effect, that we are withdrawing our historically wrong assumption that the land was not theirs, that those people did not exist and that we took it under wrongful and illegal circumstances? Of course, the right seminality is that we recognised the right of the indigenous people through that deed of grant to maintain in their ownership, their rights, the land which had always been theirs and to simply recognise the pre-existing right they had before we arrived over the last couple of centuries.

It is a very difficult and trying time for this nation. The controversy seems to be at a level unprecedented in my lifetime. It is one that we all have to account ourselves in. It is one that challenges us all. But, as many people in the indigenous population of this country have made it so clear, it is one that we must address and rectify, hence the need for reconciliation in the fullest sense of that word.

The mealy-mouthed and mealy‐worded motion of the government echoes all the shortcomings of the past and embraces with no success any of the challenges which will make the future the positive, all inclusive and wholesome prospect that the past has not been. I, therefore, support the opposition's amendments.

In reflecting on the words of other speakers that the symbolism is of itself important, I point to that last amendment which would have the plaque that Faith Bandler and the Governor-General revealed today in Melbourne placed in this parliament, not in the museum of Old Parliament House. I am amazed that the government does not understand the symbolism of that amendment to the original Labor proposition that that plaque should be in this parliament when it has altered it to confine the plaque to the museum down the road—wrong symbolism, wrong attitude, failure to relate and empathise. We can do better than that. We must do better than that, and I hope the Senate will endorse the opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Today marks the 30th anniversary of the 1967 referendum which gave the Commonwealth the power to make special laws for the people of any race, in particular Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I must say to this chamber that I was very honoured and pleased to have been part of that great movement to ensure that that referendum was passed by this parliament and was supported by the people generally. I was a member of the ACTU executive at that time and in the lead-up to the referendum bill going through the parliament. The previous Minister for Labour and National Service, Harold Holt, who subsequently, of course, became Prime Minister, was quite strongly in favour of this particular measure.

SPEECH.PARA: There was, as we all know, an overwhelming vote—over 90 per cent of the Australian electorate voted in favour of the proposition. Of course, we must realise that the proposition was to enable our parliament, the Commonwealth, to make laws, as I have said, for the peace, order and good government of this nation.

As has been mentioned during this particular debate, Prime Minister Harold Holt in 1967 referred to the need for this power to be exercised in the best interests of the Aboriginal people. The Deputy Leader of the Australian Country Party at that particular time, Doug Anthony, indicated also that this power should be exercised for the benefit of the Aboriginal people. Gough Whitlam, again, was very strong in his support for this proposition. The next year, which was 1968, he was also in support of me.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't win them all, can you?
—I remind Senator Bolkus that Gough Whitlam was in support of my right to represent Tasmania on the federal executive of the Australian Labor Party. That is an aside, and I could not help it.

BREAK.PARA: It is a pity really that we do not have a motion here before us to which we are able to unanimously subscribe. I am feeling quite disappointed about that. It is a bit of a shame that that sort of division should be here within this parliament when such unanimity, almost unanimity, was evident during the 1967 discussions, debate and, of course, referendum.

I was sorry to hear some political point scoring during the debate, because I do not think that the difference between the government's proposal and the opposition's amendments amount to that much. I do not agree with what Senator Brown said, that the government's proposal is mealy-mouthed and mealy-worded. I do not think that we should really reflect on the motives of other members of parliament.

But I do indicate to the government that it ought to have another look at the amendments that have been put forward by the opposition, because I really feel that they could quite comfortably live with those amendments. The only thing that I can see in those amendments that might possibly give some concern perhaps to the government at least is in the new paragraph (5), if it is adopted, which states:
recognises the critical importance to indigenous Australians and the wider Australian community of a continuing reconciliation process—
I think the government agrees with that—
based on understanding of and frank apologies for what has gone wrong in the past, and total commitment to equal respect in the future;

I am not going to prejudge this idea of an official apology by the government until the report is tabled and one has a good look at it. The Prime Minister himself, as I understand it, made an apology in a personal sense on his own behalf, and presumably others, to the Reconciliation Convention in Melbourne yesterday.

The second thing that is in the amendments which the government might find possible difficulty with—I do not know—relates to whether or not the commemorative plaque should be housed within new Parliament House or Old Parliament House. I really cannot understand what all the fuss is about. I do indicate that I will be supporting the amendment. I also indicate that there are people who are making contributions to this particular matter, on the anniversary of this referendum, which will be far more eloquent than mine. I refer of course to Sir William Deane.

I have only just been handed a copy of Sir William Deane's address to the Reconciliation Convention in Melbourne today. I believe that what I should do right now is to desist from saying anything further in this chamber and read what Sir William Deane has said about that marvellous victory for commonsense and indeed marvellous victory for truth and morality in this country in 1967.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do think that it is a matter of regret that the Labor Party have thought that this is the occasion for a bit of partisan politics and that Senator Bolkus thought that it was an appropriate time to be attacking the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

SPEECH.PARA: I would have thought that, if ever there was an occasion when parliamentarians across party lines might come together to express a commitment to help redress the wrongs of the past, to overcome the disadvantages that Aboriginal people still face and to work towards achieving justice for Aboriginal people, today was the day. But Senator Bolkus obviously feels that there are some votes to be won in this issue somewhere and simply could not resist the temptation.

It is unfortunate, Senator Harradine, that it was not possible to agree on a set of words across the chamber. Attempts were made during the course of the day to do so. It was the view of the government, and remains the view of the government, that the wording that we have provided in the terms of this motion does appropriately cover all of the issues that are before us today.

The first is to recognise the importance of this occasion as the 30th anniversary of the referendum; to recognise even further the symbolism of over 90 per cent of the Australian community voting in support of the referendum and what that indicates in terms of the wish of the Australian people—that the Commonwealth government play a positive role to the benefit of the Aboriginal people of Australia; to recognise in fact that the Commonwealth has sought to address the profound economic and social disadvantage but that we have not yet succeeded and that there is more to be done; to specifically state a commitment to the reconciliation process as an effort to address past injustices, but as part of a cooperative effort to build a better future for all Australians; and to support the request that the plaque be symbolically placed in the Old Parliament House.

The wording apparently was unsatisfactory from the perspective of the Labor Party and I think really the issue of consequence to the Labor Party was their first amendment, and that is in their proposed alternative paragraph (3) which I will come to in a moment.

There were two other matters which Senator Harradine identified as he sought to interpret the differences between the parties. The third was in fact the issue as to whether the plaque ought to be in the Old Parliament House or the new Parliament House. I notice we both claim that we are supporting a request. I cannot see that the request can be to the same place, so there is obviously some difference of understanding there and I would have thought that that could be easily resolved.

The second was the issue of apology, which really goes to the debate that is still to come on the issue of the separation of children. As Senator Harradine acknowledged, the Prime Minister was clear in his position on that issue yesterday when he said at the reconciliation conference in Melbourne:

Clearly, there were injustices done and no‐one should obscure or minimise them. We need to acknowledge as a nation what European settlement has meant for the first Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and in particular the assault on their traditions and the discrimination and violence which they endured over many decades.
He went on to say:

Let me make this clear. Personally, I feel deep sorrow for those of my fellow Australians who have suffered injustices under the practices of past generations towards indigenous people. Equally, I am sorry for the hurt and trauma many people here today may continue to feel as a consequence of those practices.
And later:

BREAK.PARA: We must acknowledge past wrongs, understand that they still cause a great deal of personal distress and resolve to improve areas of indigenous disadvantage, both now and in the future.

I would have thought that the position of the Prime Minister, as he stated publicly yesterday, is absolutely clear. We recognise mistakes have been made in the past. It is much easier, years after, to recognise that fact but, nevertheless, with the benefit of hindsight we recognise it and we recognise a responsibility to do something about it and work to overcome injustice and disadvantage. I really do not think that is the issue that has caused division on this matter. The issue that has caused division was the first one I mentioned, that is, the determination of the Labor Party to include within this motion today the words that the power conferred by the referendum would `only be used for the benefit of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people'.

There is no doubt that the referendum was passed for the benefit of the Aboriginal people and that is what over 90 per cent of Australians voted for. But what is now being said by the Labor Party, really in an attempt to attack our efforts to address the Wik judgment in terms of legislation in this place, is that it should be necessary to prove that each and every specific law is for the benefit of the Aboriginal people. That is not as it has been interpreted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?

—Because—if I might respond to the interjection, Mr Acting Deputy President—it is a simplistic approach. On that basis the High Court may well have struck down the Native Title Act. The Native Title Act of the Labor Party was an attempt to address, in terms of public administration, the Mabo judgment, in the same way that we have a responsibility to address, in terms of public administration, the Wik judgment. But to give the narrow interpretation now being sought to be applied by the Labor Party for its partisan political purposes to our efforts to address Wik, which they were not prepared to accept in addressing Mabo, is inappropriate. The important thing is that the law as a whole, the power to legislate provided by the change to the constitution, was for the benefit of the Aboriginal people. And so it should be.

BREAK.PARA: The interpretation that the Labor Party now seeks to adopt, which is inconsistent with the interpretation that has been applied by the majority of the High Court, is simply being applied in this effort for partisan political purposes and that is the only real reason that the Labor Party was determined to have this amendment—so that they could then attack the coalition's legislative response. That, I guess, is the consequence of changing sides in this chamber, Senator Bolkus. When this chamber addressed the native title legislation, it was different from what it is going to be when you have to address the legislation of this government that will flow from the Wik judgment, in our attempt to try to find a workable balance in administrative terms out of that judgment. We are not going to allow you to interpret this amendment in a way that suits your purposes by having us vote for it, and therefore we have no alternative but to vote against it.

As I said, unfortunately the Labor Party was determined from the start to introduce a note of partisan politics into this debate. They have succeeded in doing that, so they will not get an unanimous outcome today and I think history will record that as a disappointment from today's effort, but so it must be. It is certainly not the preference of the Australian government. It is unfortunately the determination of the Australian Labor Party that still regrettably sees a vote or two in this issue.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the Senate the fact that members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 are the only Australians to be deliberately excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable `active service'. Australian Archives records show that the only reason for the exclusion was to save money. Members of the Australian Army and Air Force serving in Malaya were not excluded, and the costs associated with the land forces was one of the main reasons for the exclusion of the Navy. An injustice was done which later events have compounded.

There are two forms of benefits for ex‐servicemen, Disability Pensions for war caused disabilities (denied the sailors referred to but introduced in 1972 for `Defence Service' within Australia) and Service Pensions. Allied veterans of 55 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Vietnam War can have qualifying eligibility for Service Pensions under the Act. Service by 5 countries in Vietnam was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded. The Department of Veterans' Affairs confirms that 686 ex‐members of the South Vietnamese Armed Forces are in receipt of Australian Service Pensions; 571 on married rate and 115 on single rate. In effect, 1,257 Service Pensions, denied to ex‐members of the RAN, are being paid for serving alongside Australians in Vietnam.
It is claimed that:

(a) Naval personnel were engaged on operational duties that applied to all other Australian service personnel serving overseas on `active service'. They bombarded enemy positions in Malaya and secretly intercepted enemy communications;

(b) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, none of which appear on the Roll of Honour at the Australian War Memorial;

(c) the Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this is documented in Navy Office Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy. The RAN was then apparently `unallotted' secretly to enable the excluding legislation to be introduced;

(d) the Department of Veterans' Affairs has said it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not, allegedly, be found.

(e) Naval personnel were not, as claimed, bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements, introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962. This Act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended;

(f) as Australian citizens serving with the Royal Australian Navy they complied with three of the four requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply to Malaya.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to remove the discriminatory exclusion in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of honourable `active service' with the Royal Australian Navy in direct support of British and Malayan forces during the Malayan Emergency between 1955 and 1960.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned demand the Australian Government honour its commitment to the Higher Education sector as stated in the Liberal and National Parties' Higher Education Policy.
We demand the Australian Government:

Raise the level of Austudy above the poverty line.
Lower the age of independence to 21.
Review the differential HECS.
Abolish up‐front fees for undergraduate places.

PETITION.TITLE: Native Title
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of Australia:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House our concerns about proposals to introduce legislation to extinguish native title. We feel such legislation would breach Australia's international obligations to uphold the principles of the Racial Discrimination Act. Such legislation would also severely impede the reconciliation process, and would rob Aboriginal people of their dignity and right to self‐determination.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:

PARA.TAB: reject proposals to extinguish Aboriginal rights to native title under Common Law;
ensure any legislation passed maintains the integrity of the Racial Discrimination Act and respects the High Court's native title decisions;
encourage negotiated agreements.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate their extreme concern at the proposal to charge entry fees for people needing nursing home care. Furthermore, the petitioners are extremely concerned that the charging of up front entry fees will force people to sell their homes in order to gain a nursing home bed.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate act to ensure that access to nursing home care is available on the basis of need and further that the family home is exempt from any asset test used to determine eligibility for such care.

PETITION.TITLE: Scholarships: Taxation

PETITION.TITLE: Refugees
PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned draw attention to the Senate of our opposition to changes to refugee and immigration decision making and review tribunal, by removing one stage of the process and by imposing a $1,000.00 fee.

Mr Ruddock, the Minister has stated `that this will act as a deterrent to those abusing the system and is to discourage frivolous applications in addition to restriction on work rights and review application periods'.

Dear Senator O'Chee
LIFE INSURANCE ACT 1995
REGULATION 10.05B
Thank you for your letter dated 20 February 1997, concerning privacy issues relating to Regulation 10.05B under the Life Insurance Act 1995 (the 1995 Act).
I sought a response to the matters raised in your letter from the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (the `Commission'), which I have now received, and outline below.

Regulation 10.05B provides that the Commissioner may publish any information relating to unclaimed moneys. Your question was whether, in developing the regulation, the Privacy Commissioner was consulted.

The Commission, in developing the regulation in conjunction with the Attorney‐General's Office of Legislative Drafting, did not consult the Privacy Commissioner. However, privacy issues were the reason for, and were considered in, developing the regulation. Since your letter, the Commission has contacted the Privacy Commission, and their response is included in the following paragraphs.

The Life Insurance Act 1945 contained a similar provision to that contained in Regulation 10.05B, which allowed gazettal of unclaimed moneys information (section 106(8)). The policy position in developing the 1995 Act was to allow publication of the same information in a less expensive format and therefore, to allow for flexibility in publication. It was always the intention to publish this informa tion, and I note that you have recognised the appropriateness of the publication.

The Commission recognised the need for the insertion of a specific regulation after identifying that the disclosure of personal information, without legislative authorisation, may breach Information Privacy Principles. While the policy intent was to publish the information, the legislation did not specifically provide for publication. Disclosure of personal information is necessary in order for a person to determine whether or not they are entitled to make a claim. Information Privacy Principles allows disclosure of personal information in a record where such disclosure is authorised by or under law.
The Privacy Commissioner was not consulted in developing the regulation because the insertion of the regulation:
a) was essential to allow claimants to identify unclaimed moneys; and
b) facilitated the continuation of previous policy.

However, given your letter, the Commission contacted the Privacy Commission on 9 May 1997, and sought comment on the proposed Regulation. Their response notes the strong public interest grounds for allowing the information to be published. However, while not objecting in principle to the Regulation allowing publication of information, the inclusion of amounts owing is questioned, as it may constitute an unwarranted disclosure of an individual's affairs, and potentially encourage misrepresentation of that individual.

The Commission accepts this advice, and notes that the regulation states that the Commissioner may publish any of the information contained in an unclaimed monies return. Therefore, the Commissioner may choose not to publish amounts (which I note were published under the 1945 Act). In accordance with the Privacy Commission's advice, the Commission will not include amounts owing in any publication of unclaimed moneys.
I hope that this information adequately addresses your Committee's concerns.
Yours sincerely
ROD KEMP
