SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to present the government's response to the report of the Senate Economics Legislation Committee entitled Inquiry into public equity in Telstra Corporation Ltd . I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

The government accepts the majority recommendation of the Senate Economics Committee Inquiry into Public Equity in Telstra Corporation that the partial sale of Telstra be by way of an issue of ordinary equity in the company.
The government concurs with the Committee's view that this will be the most effective way of realising the government's objectives for the partial sale which are:
. exposure of Telstra to capital market disciplines and scrutiny together with increasing competition from mid 1997 which will be an essential driver of efficiencies in the Company;
. a more efficient Telstra brought about by the introduction of a more commercial focus by Telstra management;
. the promotion of an internationally competitive, low cost, innovative telecommunications industry;
. wider share ownership, including by Telstra employees, in one of the fastest growing dynamic industries of the economy; and
. sale proceeds to fund the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, $1.1 billion, and for the retirement of public debt.

The government considers that ordinary shares are optimal as a driver of efficiencies, given that they provide the most direct linkage between company performance and investor returns. Telstra, by its own admission lags world best practice on a number of key efficiency measures for the telecommunications sector. Capital raising options which do not directly link company performance with investor returns would not satisfy this objective.

The government also agrees with the majority report of the Committee that a capital raising in the region of $8‐10 billion is best undertaken by way of ordinary equity, given the size of the market for such securities relative to the much smaller, and less well understood, market for hybrid securities in Australia.

While recognising that hybrid securities may provide a useful form of capital raising in certain circumstances, the government is mindful of the disadvantages identified in the Committee's report regarding the exclusive use of various types of hybrid securities for the Telstra offer. The range of hybrid securities discussed in the majority report is very broad, encompassing very different features within both redeemable preference share and converting preference share structures. The majority report identifies advantages for Telstra and for the government's wider reform objectives in the use of ordinary equity, in preference to widespread use of hybrid securities of an equity character. Use of hybrid securities of debt character, even apart from any tax issues, would lack the advantages for Telstra and for the government's program that ordinary equity, and securities of an equity character, would have.

The report makes a number of statements about the tax treatment of various hybrid instruments in describing the advantages and disadvantages of the various fund raising options. Hybrid securities may be structured to combine a range of characteristics, so that their resemblance to ordinary debt or to ordinary equity is a matter of degree. Generally, however, a particular hybrid security will be predominantly of a debt or of an equity character. This does not merely depend on the formal question of whether it is structured as, say, a converting preference share or as a redeemable preference share.

Many different terms and conditions may be attached to hybrid instruments. They may be cumulative, or non‐cumulative. They may be redeemable, or non‐redeemable; convertible, or non‐convertible. They may be redeemed or converted on a basis which gives the investor the benefit, the risk, or both of movement in the market price for ordinary equity; or they may be redeemed or converted on a basis which gives no such benefit or risk. They may participate fully in control of the issuer, or they may have only limited rights. Whether a particular hybrid instrument is more of a debt or of an equity character depends on the mix of these, and other, terms. However, where an instrument is predominantly of an equity character, the risks and benefits reflected in its redemption or conversion value will generally have to be based on the market value of the issuer—and so the evidence to the Committee suggests that it is practically difficult to market a hybrid instrument of an equity character unless there is an open market for the equity in the issuer.

Section 46D of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 is designed to apply to particular hybrid securities that are essentially of a debt character. Preference shares may have a debt character, and the Treasury advised that a particular form of preference share initially discussed by Senator Harradine would be likely to have that character and would be likely to attract the operation of section 46D. However, the Treasury has consistently advised that the status of a hybrid instrument can only be determined by reference to all its terms, and not by reference to whether it is, in legal form, a redeemable preference share or a converting preference share. It is not the intention of section 46D that redeemable preference shares, no matter at whose option redeemable, must be characterised as always debt or always equity.

Whether the tax treatment of hybrid securities is appropriate, and whether that treatment is fully consistent with the characterisation of a security as debt or as equity, are difficult questions. These questions were not part of the terms of reference of the inquiry, and so could not attract a full range of submissions or evidence from all those who might have an interest in those questions. The government considers that any consideration of the appropriateness of section 46D would depend on an analysis of these questions, taking account of the different tax treatments of debt and of equity and of the scope of tax avoidance that this raises. Such an analysis was outside the scope of the inquiry.

Where the line between debt and equity ought to be drawn for tax purposes is considered in the Issues Paper—Taxation of Financial Arrangements, TOFA, released by the Australian Taxation Office and Treasury in December 1996. Submissions on the TOFA proposals have been requested from all interested parties.

Senator Harradine's minority report focuses on issues in relation to the sale of infrastructure assets as a primary reason for using redeemable preference shares or some other type of security which would not give rise to private ownership of Telstra's network infrastructure. The regulatory regime for the telecommunications sector, as set out in the Telecommunications Act 1997, recognises the essential nature of these facilities and recognises that there are some specific circumstances where it may be commercially unattractive to construct competing infrastructure.

The government considers that the competitive safeguards and universal service obligation contained in the 1997 telecommunications legislation will provide a sound basis for regulating access to telecommunications network infrastructure, and its provision in areas where competition will develop more slowly, independent of whether such infrastructure is publicly or privately owned.

The government's objectives for the partial privatisation of Telstra reflect the Company's strategic importance in the fastest growing sector in the Australian economy. In such an operating environment, injection of private capital is the surest way to preserve the long term value of Telstra as a major Australian company, through the presence of incentives which optimise feedback on performance. Private equity owners are also more tolerant of the risks of investment in emerging markets than the public sector and are therefore more willing to earn risk related returns. Such an investment mind‐set is crucial to Telstra moving forward in a rapidly changing market place.

The injection of private equity ownership is not a process that can be reversed, as mentioned in Senator Harradine's minority report, without the creating the potential for substantial damage to investors' interests, including uncertainty, impeding the effective functioning of capital markets and diminishing the shareholder value of Telstra as a commercial enterprise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to this government response to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee inquiry into the Telstra Corporation—in particular, to the proposal floated by Senator Harradine that the financing of the privatisation of Telstra could be undertaken and used for debt management through shareholdings.

SPEECH.PARA: This report essentially comes down in a totally predictable manner. It upholds the view that the government's policy is best served by the government following its own policy. What a remarkable achievement! What a remarkable achievement that we have discovered with this government response! It states:

The government accepts the majority recommendation of the Senate Economics Committee Inquiry into Public Equity in Telstra Corporation that the partial sale of Telstra be by way of an issue of ordinary equity in the company.
What an extraordinary discovery!

What troubles me most is that this extraordinary discovery was made well before this inquiry was actually held. It was made well before the deal was struck to secure the privatisation of Telstra. I find that a farce. I find it extraordinary that this matter could have been given the attention, the public debate and the time that it was when it was quite clear right from the word go that this government was predicating its financing of a whole range of quite nefarious activities upon the privatisation of Telstra, and it was going to secure the privatisation through the securing of votes in this chamber. What we discover is that the government has had an inquiry into its own policy and come up with the conclusion that its own policy was right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amazing.

—Absolutely extraordinary. What troubles me most is that Senator Harradine would have known that as well. That is what is most disturbing—that there was any serious consideration of this measure, given the arrangements that had actually been undertaken to secure the privatisation of Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: We well know just how far those arrangements went on the matters that have come before this Senate on a number of occasions in recent times. We well know the way in which the majorities were put together to secure the passage of this particular legislation through the Senate.

For my mind, the fundamental issues remain the same in terms of the privatisation of Telstra. There has been no satisfaction in terms of meeting those very grave community concerns about allowing access to advanced telecommunications services for all Australians rather than just the few. There has been no satisfaction of the community concerns about the services being available on the basis of the highest possible equality and the lowest possible price. There has been no satisfaction of public concerns about the fact that public finances themselves are going to be put at risk as a result of this privatisation.

Before this budget was announced, we saw measures undertaken to borrow $3 billion, financed by the taxpayers, through Telstra in such a manner as to provide international competitiveness by lifting the level of public debt for Telstra. There was no real protection for Australians in terms of increased foreign ownership that will arise directly as a result of that increased debt level. There was no protection for Australians in terms of ownership of what is now and what will be until the time the float actually takes place a publicly owned asset of the Australian people.

There has been no satisfaction. If anything, it is quite the contrary. Devastation has been wrought upon Telstra—and especially the Telstra workers—as a result of the restructuring of that corporation in such a manner that ensures that its focus is now away from community concerns and is instead on more narrow, commercial concerns and the protection of shareholders into the future. In terms of the prospectus, it is quiet apparent that the emphasis in Telstra is now away from its community service obligations and towards the stock markets and those who make up the power behind the whole operation that we see, in terms of the international corporations seeking to get their hands on Australia's telecommunications industry.

There is no satisfaction for the local manufacturing industry. They are deeply concerned about the prospect of the loss of valuable contracts and are worried about the importance of our domestic economic sovereignty with the privatisation of Telstra. So those fundamental issues are not resolved.

What I find quite extraordinary in this response is that, even in a document this thin, we find that the government has not appropriately considered the matters. It has admitted quite clearly in this response that it has not even considered appropriately the matters that Senator Harradine had raised. Page 3, for instance, says:
Section 46D of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 is designed to apply to particular hybrid securities that are essentially of a debt character.
It then goes on to discuss the implications of this matter, but it says:
These questions were not part of the terms of reference of the inquiry, and so could not attract a full range of submissions or evidence from all those who might have an interest in those questions.
That is really at the nub of this matter. The deal was done. We had a sop to Senator Harradine that there be a reference to a committee.
Senator Hogg interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —A very limited report was put together, and so it ought to be limited, because they knew the answer, as Senator Hogg has indicated. They knew the answer from day one. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.PARA: I was drawing the Senate's attention to the inadequacies of this report and to the quite shameful way in which Telstra has been sold off. An inquiry has been established into Senator Harradine's proposals to try to find alternatives to the direct privatisation of Telstra.

This government has come down with this report, the answers to which it knew before it set up this inquiry. That is why there is such a flimsy response here. Even within this flimsy response, quite specific reference is made to quite important matters not being adequately considered. They were not adequately considered because the government knew the answers that it wanted to find before it established the inquiry. It had the arrangements in place to secure the privatisation of Telstra. In particular, it had the commitment of Senator Harradine to support the privatisation of Telstra. It had the support of Senator Colston and it had to find a mechanism to try to find a sop to Senator Harradine to justify the consideration that it had given to this matter, which they had rejected time and again, both privately and publicly.

It is an extraordinary farce that we engage in this exercise whereby consideration could possibly be given to a measure which the government had rejected because it knew it had the means by which to secure the passage of the legislation through this chamber.

The fundamental concerns remain with the privatisation of Telstra. The Australian people are being grossly short‐changed by the actions of this government in taking away a public asset and turning it into private hands, to the great disadvantage of the majority of Australians, particularly Australians who live in regional areas. That is the case in Tasmania and Queensland but especially areas in Victoria and New South Wales, which paid disproportionately for the actions of this government to find the various devices to provide that fig leaf of respectability for the actions taken by senators in this parliament to support this legislation.

The sale of Telstra will go down as one of the great disgraces of this parliament. One of the great public corporations has been lost to the people of this country as a result of the actions of this government. I believe they will be actions that this government will come to regret. I suspect that a legacy that many generations of Australia will have to bear will be the loss of this great corporation and the transfer of the public benefit to private benefit. There will be a great consequence and disadvantage to Australians, wherever they may be.

In respect of this particular matter—the report of the Economics Legislation Committee's inquiry into public equity in Telstra Corporation Ltd—I genuinely put forth the proposal that there should be redeemable preference shares. SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to make a statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always been a great supporter of the Australian National Audit Office, particularly their independence, and I have helped them on a number of reports they have made. I have always made the point over the years, though, that when they report on defence matters their methodology limits them from accurately assessing those capabilities in so far as there is always a reserve capability inherent in the defence forces and, if you apply the normal commercial standards of the bottom line judgment, you will always come out with some erroneous figures.

SPEECH.PARA: This report opens with a rather shock statement that it costs $6,800 per annum, by their methodology, to maintain a state of health in every member, male and female, serving in the Australian Defence Force. It also quotes a figure of $215 million as the asset value of health facilities in the Defence Force. All of this is in a report that runs to roughly 100 pages, which, in the usual style, has been presented to us but half an hour before it reaches the Senate so that we do not have time to do anything other than skim it.

The problem here is that we do maintain a higher level of health in the defence forces than exists in the general public. Because we maintain that higher level of health, it always means that a lot of elective choices, both in medicine and dentistry, are implemented which would not happen with a private person living in the civilian community. There is also a high emphasis on preventive medicine because the service personnel, male and female, start with the highest of medical standards and it is important, having invested money in their training, that they are maintained in a high state of health. This in part explains the higher cost of medical and dental services to members of the Australian Defence Force. I am not saying that that is the sole reason for it, and I am certainly not saying that there are no inefficiencies in the program, but there is simply no recognition of the factors that I have mentioned in the report as I see it.

I want to deal briefly with the reserve capabilities. The provision of medical services for the defence forces does require the capability to deal with people who are injured in hostilities, on active service. Those facilities are extremely expensive. If we look at what has happened this century and we look at the huge casualty rates for the First World War and we look at the casualty rates for the Second World War, when medical technology was nowhere near as sophisticated as it is today, we see that there is a huge difference in the number of deaths of personnel in those two conflicts. That was due to the improved medical services—getting better antibiotic drugs and better surgical procedures principally—available to troops who were wounded in the field. Of course, in Vietnam it was only 20 or 25 minutes from injury to a casualty clearing station by helicopter evacuation. Again, we saw a significant lowering of the mortality rates and also morbidity rates.

The provision of all those facilities is expensive. One of the things that happened to the ADF under the Labor government was the dismantling of the really excellent services we had which were reservist based. The specialist services in medicine and dentistry, the field hospitals and field ambulances we had were largely run down. Part of that capability has been lost and it is one of the duties of this government to reconstruct that. But that is a story for another time and another place.

One of my fears when this reserve capability is not recognised, though, is that some bureaucrats will move in and subject the few remaining hospitals that we have to a commercial support program. Then we would probably lose the few permanent hospitals that now exist in the Australian Defence Force, because I do not doubt that facilities like the new hospital at Enoggera can be privatised, and I think that the capability of the ADF would suffer enormously.

But I do believe there are savings to be made from having one stream administering the medical and the dental service for all three services. Certainly aviation medicine is different from what is required of a ship's doctor on a destroyer or something like that, but basically the differences in the medical services provided for the army, navy and air force are no greater than the differences that exist in the medical service today between anaesthetists and surgeons and physicians and endocrinologists. They are all part of the one family.

We seem to have gone down the path of the worst of the Canadian system in this country. We have not dealt with the obvious areas that could be combined. I go back many years to when I was a student and it was said then that medical services for all three services would be combined and it would be just one service. That is nearly 40 years ago and nothing has happened up until this latest defence efficiency review, and I hope that something will be implemented there. We have not done the obvious with respect to combining services but we have adopted some of the worst features of the Canadian system, and particularly with respect to putting all power in the hands of the Chief of the Defence Force and diminishing the power of the chiefs of staff, and putting all power in Headquarters ADF rather than in the individual service headquarters. Again, that is a story for another day.

I do believe that we could have a common medical service from an administrative point of view for the army, navy and air force the same as we could have a common service for cooks and for much of the technical training, certainly in the basic levels of technical training. At the end of the day, the maintenance of the health of the ADF is a big job and is a vital task. We put a lot of focus on training and equipment for the defence forces, but all of that is in vain if the personnel who operate it are not healthy when they are required to be so.

BREAK.PARA: Everyone forgets the huge problems we had in the Second World War when the army and the air force were operating in New Guinea. We had huge casualty rates from malaria until effective anti-malarial regimes were introduced both from a preventative point of view and from a chemotherapeutic point of view.

I will touch on some of the recommendations briefly. The first recommendation deals with the maintenance of a minimal level of health service resources. It is an unfortunate emphasis to be talking about the minimal level of health services rather than phrasing it in terms of maintaining the maximum level of health for members of the ADF.

Recommendation 2 deals with the apparent high cost of maintaining the health services as they are for the ADF. The inference there is that members of the defence forces get more than they would get in civilian life. One of the compensatory benefits of service in the ADF has always been that you got good medical and dental services.

Recommendation 6 proposes that the Surgeon‐General have overall administration of the health services. That is in line with what I was saying earlier, but he has to be supported with adequate resources because it is a very big job.

Recommendation 9 is quite important because it talks about a detailed costing of all ADF hospitals and medical centres. I fear there that we will lose a very considerable reserve capability if that is subject to a CSP because then we will not be able to train service personnel in a service environment. There are many more points that could be mentioned there, but there are other speakers to this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in respect of this report not to speak at great length but to put on the record a few concerns that I have arising out of this report. I notice that in the overall conclusion the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the ADF provides high‐quality health services to its members with a strong emphasis on preventative health care.
It goes on:

BREAK.PARA: Current health service administrative structures are complex and fragmented and lead to inefficiencies and inequities . . .

Whilst this may be the case, I agree with some of the sentiments expressed by Senator MacGibbon that there may be some real difficulties that the defence forces are faced with that are not apparent in other places. The report then goes on in its overall conclusion to say:
A more effective management of health services could be achieved if these structures were rationalised and placed under centralised command and control.
One would have to be very reserved in one's judgment to see how this was actually going to be applied before one could go in boots and all and accept the conclusion that has been made there.

Over in the key findings to the report, reference is made under the heading of `Organisation and staffing' to the fragmentation in the ADF health services' lines of control and there is talk there of greater coordination in that area. Again, one would have to view very carefully how this was actually implemented such that it was not a downgrading of the services provided under the ADF health services.

Again, the theme comes up under the heading of `Facilities planning and utilisation'. One sees reference there to the rationalisation of ADF hospitals and medical centres and the report goes on to say:
. . . opportunity exists to achieve economies through either the contracting out of a substantial proportion of pathology services or the development of a central ADF reference laboratory . . .

Until one can actually see the savings to be made under that sort of recommendation, one must have some doubts because one might be sacrificing the efficiency of our Defence Force medical services by contracting out such services. Under `Financial administration', the report states:
As a consequence, the ADF cannot identify the full cost of operating its health services and facilities.

I can share some concern there that the costs cannot be identified but, by the same token, in a Defence Force one might not necessarily be able to get down to the exact dollars and cents as one might find in other areas. The other area of concern is in the recommendations. Recommendation 2, which Senator MacGibbon referred to, says:

The ANAO recommends that Defence assess the merits and possible implications of a member contribution for any health services additional to those required for the maintenance of individual readiness or that are outside the ADF's duty of care to its employees.

Throughout the estimates processes and other processes of this Senate, I will undoubtedly be placing close scrutiny on the application of this audit report to find out more of the efficiencies that can be gained and if they are really material efficiencies that will assist the defence forces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to this Australian National Audit Office report today, I am mindful of one of the key findings, and that is `potential for achieving economies through rationalisation or civilianisation of non-operational services'. I refer to the use of the word `rationalisation'. Lately, we have seen the use of this word, which has meant cutting costs, cutting services and making users pay. I just hope that that is not what is being anticipated there.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two areas that I would like to briefly dwell on tonight and, like other senators, I will be following up this in estimates as well. The first one is organisation and staffing. I notice that paragraph 3.6 deals with a medical assistants course. I have some concerns about some of the lesser health professionals within the ADF, other than doctors, nurses, et cetera.

I wonder about some of the training—I will be pursuing this—that medical assistants, sick bay attendants and the like in the three services are given and whether it is comparable with civilian training. I am wondering how these matters are dealt with in the ADF. I know that there would be emergency times out in the field and in combat, but this is something that we have to watch very carefully.

One recommendation causes me great concern, and I speak here as a registered nurse and as a member of the Royal College of Nursing in the New South Wales College. That is recommendation No. 6, which states:

The ANAO recommends that the Surgeon General be given responsibility for the command and control of all ADF health resources, that appropriate human and financial resourcing be transferred to OSGADF and that the formal agreements be developed with operational commanders in relation to the provision of resources for operational purposes.
I do not have a not a problem with that, but I have a problem with what might well be their interpretation of all health resources going to the Surgeon General. Paragraph 3.16 of the report states:
The ANAO considers that more effective management of health services could be achieved if the Surgeon General had full control, rather than technical control, of ADF health services.

The question I ask is: what gives a doctor the right to decide what nursing treatment and what nursing care is the appropriate nursing care? Nurses these days, the senior nurses within the ADF, are highly qualified. They have degrees; they have qualifications in specialist areas of nursing. Most of them have higher qualifications in health administration—not just nursing administration, but health administration. Because of their specific expertise within the ADF, one must look at what qualifications they would bring to the general health management within the ADF. There are other health professionals also, not just doctors.

It is incumbent upon the ADF to step forward into the 21st century, not back into the 19th century and the days of the Crimean War when Florence Nightingale was rendering her nursing aid to soldiers at the front. It is incumbent upon the ADF to recognise the professional qualifications, skills and training that people in the health services in the ADF—other than doctors—have obtained. I do not want to appear to be denigrating the skills and the qualifications of the Surgeon General or any of the doctors that are working within the ADF health services, but I have a grave concern, if I am interpreting this correctly—I hope I am interpreting this the wrong way—that nursing decisions will be taken out of the hands of nurses; dental decisions will be taken out of the hands of dentists; and physiotherapy decisions will be taken out of the hands of physiotherapists.

Gone are the days when the doctor had sole control and command of what was the best thing for a patient. Patient care is a team effort these days; all people should be involved. There is no reason why ADF health requirements and health needs should be any different from anybody else's health needs. I will certainly be pursuing that with a great deal more interest as time goes on.

The other issue that I find interesting is that they actually start to look at occupational health and safety. When women started to become active within the ADF, when they started to have jobs in non-traditional roles and when they started to get out closer to the front line, we suddenly had people saying, `Oh, but a woman can't lift a 50-pounder'—or whatever the gun size was or whatever the shell size was—`She's too frail; she's too fragile. She can't lift those sorts of weights, lump that sort of load, move whatever has to be moved.'

BREAK.PARA: They failed to take into consideration that the strength of some women can be greater than the strength of a small, slightly built male. But because someone was a male in the ADF, it was assumed that they could therefore move this object. Women going into the ADF has brought about a reassessment in some cases of just what skills are needed and what the procedures are for moving and carrying. They are encouraging people to utilise ergonomically safe practices within occupational health and safety guidelines.

It is a pretty poor indictment, I think, that the ADF does not know actuarially just what the cost is of occupational health and safety injuries and problems and that most of those problems come to light when someone is discharged or separated from the ADF and they put in claims before they leave so that they will be recognised if problems come later in life. One needs to look very carefully at the situations that we place people in, the things we ask them to do and the loads we ask them to lift and manoeuvre. I know that, on occasions, they will be required to move large, heavy loads and to undertake this work, but the ADF needs to apply a lot of the same principles that we are applying to occupational health and safety everywhere else in this country, and that deal with the safety of the workers. It is a very important issue and I am glad that it is being looked at and that a number of recommendations have been made. I look forward to continuing to pursue the outcome of these recommendations and their future direction. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (WORK FOR THE DOLE) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I table a correction to the explanatory memorandum and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.
The government believes that the work for the dole initiative recently outlined by the Prime Minister will have substantial benefits to the individual participants and the community.

Since it was announced the government has received strong public support for the work for the dole initiative. Many Australians believe that it is fair and reasonable that those being supported by the community should make a contribution in return.
Young people themselves are also looking for ways to contribute positively to the community.

The value of the work for the dole initiative lies in bringing young unemployed people back into a work culture to help instil a positive attitude to work. It will give young people a chance to engage with the community rather than being alienated from it.

This bill would provide for the changes necessary to implement the government's work for the dole initiative in a way which is consistent with feedback the government has had from the community. At the same time the initiative is based firmly on the principle of mutual obligation: that it is fair and just that people receiving unemployment allowances be asked to make a contribution to the community in return.

The government recognises that the work for the dole initiative is not a solution to youth unemployment and has not represented as such. Real jobs can only be created by the government providing a business environment that secures our economic future. The government's strong but fair budget has put downward pressure on interest rates. Policies for small business will reduce the paperwork burden for small business, and capital gains tax relief on the sale of businesses provides an incentive to small business owners to expand their businesses. The abolition of the previous government's unfair dismissal laws has removed a significant disincentive for business to take on new employees and it will encourage more productive labour relations.

The government recognises that the particular disadvantages young people face in getting jobs are structural—the low skilled jobs that young people used to take on leaving school have gradually disappeared and those jobs that remain are increasingly being taken by older and more experienced job seekers. Fundamental reforms are necessary to deal with this—to make sure that young people are better prepared before they enter the labour market. We need to strengthen the relationship between schools and the workplace to provide young people with the means to overcome these disadvantages.

A number of recent government initiatives are already addressing these fundamental issues. These include the new national apprenticeship and traineeship system, our numeracy and literacy strategy to ensure that students acquire appropriate standards of competence in these areas and the introduction of incentives to complete vocational education courses through the jobs pathway program which provides job placement assistance to those students who successfully complete vocational education courses in year 11 and year 12.

The introduction of pilot work for the dole projects should also be seen in the broader context of the government's commitments to young Australians through the government's reforms to employment services, legislation for which is also currently before the parliament. Complementary strategies are also being put in place to address other important youth issues such as family breakdown, youth suicide and homelessness.

The government considers the work for the dole initiative will combat the drift to despair and despondency felt by many unemployed young people. The government considers that young job seekers should be given the chance to add to their experience and prove their work ethic through participation in projects which are supported by the community and will be of lasting value to the community.
The aim of this legislation is to establish the framework necessary for implementation of pilot work for the dole projects. In particular the bill would amend the Social Security Act 1991 to:
Remove provisions precluding measures to compel a person to work in return for the payment of unemployment allowance;
Enable a person to voluntarily participate in a programme of work which has been approved by the employment secretary or to be required to participate in such a programme;
Provide for participation in an approved programme of work to be included in Newstart activity agreements;
Provide for an approved programme of work supplement of $20 per fortnight for participants.

Amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 would also establish that participation in work for the dole would not give rise to an employer/employee relationship for the purposes of the following acts:
The Occupational Health And Safety (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1991;
The Safety, Rehabilitation And Compensation Act 1988;
The Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992; or
The Workplace Relations Act 1996.

While it is expected that participation in work for the dole projects would be largely voluntary, the bill provides that a person may be required to work in a programme of work approved by the employment secretary in return for the payment of unemployment allowance.

A person may only be required to participate in a work for the dole project if they are in receipt of full rate unemployment allowance and there is no risk to personal health or any contravention of occupational health and safety laws.

The government recognises that participants in work for the dole projects will incur additional costs. The bill provides that an extra $20 per fortnight be paid as a supplement to their unemployment allowance in recognition of the additional costs of participating in work for the dole projects.

The government is cognisant of its international obligations. It has taken advice of the Attorney‐General's Department that a work for the dole initiative should not contravene our international obligations, provided that the work offered under work for the dole is "suitable and reasonable" for that person. The fact that payment of unemployment allowance is not based on any prior mandatory contribution, combined with the positive benefits of work for the dole for participants means that the initiative should be regarded as reasonable in its requirement of a contribution to the community from participants.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Pilot work for the dole projects

SPEECH.PARA: Within the legislative framework, we envisage publicly seeking submissions across the whole of Australia. Submissions would be price competitive. Host organisations would be responsible for supervision, essential training, any transportation costs to work sites, minor personal equipment and required clothing such as safety boots or clothing necessary for public contact situations. Appropriate insurance coverage will be arranged.

Regions with highest levels of youth unemployment would be the focus of the pilots, with an emphasis on non‐metropolitan regions. About 50 pilot projects would be allocated to these identified regions, with about another 20 projects available to ensure that quality projects from anywhere could be approved having regard to the need for broad geographic coverage during the pilot phase.

The government is targeting regional Australia in the pilot stage for many reasons, not the least of which is because our rural communities perhaps best illustrate the disastrous results of thirteen years of Labor's economic mismanagement. All communities have witnessed the fabric of our Australian society unravel under labor. Initiatives such as "work for the dole" are important steps towards repairing the damage of the previous government.
Pilot work for the dole projects would be for a minimum of 3 and a maximum of 12 months duration. They would be selected on the basis of criteria which would include:
The needs of the local unemployed young people;
The capacity of the sponsor to monitor and maintain the project;
The extent of contribution and support for the project from the local community;
The quality of community involvement; and
Preparedness of the community to support the participants after completion of their placement.
A primary test would be the benefit of the project to the wider community and not to a private sector interest.
A committee including expertise independent of—individuals who are well known in the community and committed to the initiative—would be involved in the final selection of projects.
The aim is to have about 10,000 places in the pilot work for the dole projects—with the first expected to start in September 1997. There would be no minimum size for projects.

Referral to projects would as far as possible be voluntary with the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency (CSDA) and the project sponsor advertising the availability of projects. If the response from volunteers did not provide enough participants, the CSDA would identify and notify eligible clients that they were to be compulsorily referred. Within certain limits, project sponsors would be given a degree of choice in relation to the selection of participants for particular projects.

Participants in the work for the dole pilots would primarily be 18 to 24 year olds who have been unemployed for at least 6 months. However, priority would be given to those unemployed for over 12 months who were not in case management or employment assistance and not likely to be referred to these within 6 months.

In some locations there may be some flexibility regarding the age and duration of unemployment of participants, especially where there were insufficient numbers of young people to fill projects. In addition, some projects would benefit significantly from including older job seekers to help supervise younger participants and pass on expertise.

"~Based on averaged national training wage award level c rates, participants would work for two six hour days if aged 18 to 20 years and two and a half six hour days if aged 21 years or over. They would be required to participate for a maximum of 6 months each.

Participants in the initiative requiring child care would be able to use existing child care arrangements for labour market programme participants so as not to disadvantage participants with children requiring care.

The work for the dole initiative is not designed to artificially manipulate the measured rate of youth unemployment. The Australian bureau of statistics has advised that it is unlikely that the initiative would have a noticeable impact on youth unemployment statistics.

The initiative is different from the previous government's programmes in that participants would continue to receive their unemployment allowance payments and would still be required to look for work. However, in recognition of the time spent on the work for the dole initiative, job search requirements for participants would be reduced to the minimum department of social security requirement of two employer contacts per fortnight. The existing standard unemployment allowance provisions of compliance and breaching arrangements would also apply to the work for the dole initiative. In line with existing arrangements, "clean slate" provisions would be adopted whereby if a person who is subject to an activity test or administrative breach agrees to a work for the dole placement their payment would be reinstated from the time of their commencement on the initiative.

Pilot work for the dole projects would be evaluated to assess the impact of the initiative on young people and to assist consideration of expansion of the initiative beyond the pilot stage, including the scope for expanding into different regions. A first report of the evaluation will provide a basis for decision making in the 1998‐99 budget.
Madam President, I commend the bill to the Senate.

TITLE.XREF: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1996 (No. 2)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 May, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Customs and Excise Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996.
—At last.

—I note that the minister says, `At last,' and I certainly join him in that sentiment. This is a bill colloquially known as the diesel fuel rebate bill. Initially, it should be said that diesel fuel taxes were imposed on vehicle users to cover the cost of road construction in Australia. However, it has now been extended and is imposed on all users of diesel fuel. Because a tax on miners, on the gas industry and on agriculturalists would be an input tax—that is, a cost to business, pushing up prices in the marketplace and making domestic producers uncompetitive—the government provides a rebate to those industries—that is, a return of their tax once paid on diesel fuel.

SPEECH.PARA: What has now happened, however, is that diesel fuel rebate has become, within the meaning of this government, a political football. It is now a revenue raiser for the government, which has sought to narrow the focus of the rebate and the entitlement for claimants as a consequence. The original purpose of the rebate has been lost.

For Australia, the cost of a litre of diesel fuel is 59c. That is a 31c per litre tax and a 28c per litre cost. If we did not have the diesel fuel tax, diesel fuel would cost 28c. The tax, as I say, is 31c. It raised, according to the budget papers, $1.6 billion in 1995‐1996. In the current financial year, it is estimated to raise $1.38 billion. It is, in budgetary terms, a big ticket item.

Before I turn to the issues that on behalf of the opposition I wish to address on this bill, can I say that I have noted the arguments of the Australian Democrats and the Greens, where they support the government's legislation. Their support is basically and broadly couched around the concept of opposing mining and supporting the environment, thus seeing mining as an anti‐environmental measure.

I reject the arguments that have been put by the Greens and the Democrats in supporting the government on this bill. Those arguments are facile in logic and, as a consequence, do not deal with the important issues of balancing development and environmental matters in a way in which the employment, the job creating needs and the economic growth of this country are balanced against the very important and vital need to protect our environmental concerns. I do not intend to deal in detail with the arguments put by my colleagues from the Australian Democrats and from the Greens.

This bill that is before the parliament is nothing more than a money grab from industry by the government. It is a bill that I would contend is unnecessary. It is a bill from which the government has largely excused the agricultural industry for political reasons—political reasons made clear by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). It is a bill that concentrates pre‐eminently on the mining sector, and it has set the mining sector a savings target of $95 million. The government has done so in order to fill the so‐called budget black hole and as an exercise in negative cost cutting.

I will cite four basic reasons for the Labor opposition opposing this legislation. Negative cost cutting is the first. What this government has not done—and the inquiry into this legislation made it very clear—is conduct a study of this industry to see what the economic, social and employment effects of changing this tax are. What it has done is decided to simply narrow the focus for the rebate, grab some $95 million out of the industry sector and push up prices by increasing costs to mining companies, making them more uncompetitive in the international marketplace. No assessment has been done of what further investment would have been generated had that money grab not occurred, what other jobs would have been created because of that further investment, or how the industry might have expanded.

One cannot argue in budgetary terms that cutting costs is the only way to get rid of a deficit. Backing industries that are the lifeblood of this country and that can grow the economy, create jobs, increase economic development and generate revenue on the revenue side of the budget is the other way of removing the deficit. This government is indicted because it has not even bothered to do these fundamental sums.

The second reason we oppose this legislation is because it unequivocally breaks an election undertaking. Before the last election the Treasurer (Mr Costello) made a great feature of saying that there would be no new taxes and no extension of existing taxes. The budget papers say that this bill will raise $440 million over four years. The explanatory memorandum gives a higher amount than that. Industry expects that this bill and the actions being taken by the government will raise some $720 million over four years. That shows not only that the government cannot do its sums but also that this is clearly an extension of tax. By narrowing the entitlement, the tax is extended and a core promise of this government is broken. That is a reason why this bill should be opposed.

The third reason I offer is the undertakings that the government has breached in its dealings with industry. I said at the beginning of my remarks that the government announced before the budget before last that the diesel fuel rebate was on the cost cutting agenda. It let off the agricultural sector for political reasons. A by‐election in the state of New South Wales, in which the National Party was defeated because of the impact of the guns issue, meant that the Prime Minister gave the NFF a wink and a nod guarantee that there would be no tax on them as far as diesel fuel rebate was concerned.

The full impact fell on the mining industry. And the mining industry around Australia—particularly in my home state of Western Australia—will be one of the areas that most severely bears this cost the government wishes to raise. The industry established a high‐level negotiating group which went into talks with the government. In those negotiations, they were faced with the threat that the rebate would be taken away entirely if the industry did not concede areas of so‐called reasonable claim. The industry went along with that proposition and conceded areas for the rebate to be pocketed by the government.

In chess terms, the industry decided to give up a few pawns in order to save their queen. There were three problems for the industry in this strategy. The first of those problems was that they did not succeed in saving their queen at all. The prime interest of the industry was to get a guarantee from the government that, by conceding areas where the rebate would be forgone, there would be no cap on growth in the remaining legitimate areas. The government has not given that guarantee and still remains in a situation of not giving that guarantee. That was the trade‐off. That is a breach of faith by the government in these negotiations and, as a consequence, I draw the chamber's attention to my second reading amendment, which I propose to move at the end of my speech.

The second reason why the strategy of the industry failed is that some of the areas they did not give up in the industry negotiations are now, by this bill, claimed by the government as their entitlement. So it was not a fair negotiation. They lost in that area as well.

Thirdly, some of the areas they gave up were vital industries which ought to be considered in their own right. But they were not front and centre industries that are affected by the mining sector and were, therefore, `soft' concessions by the mining sector.

Take the salt industry. As a consequence of this bill, if it is carried, Dampier Salt in Western Australia will pay $800,000 in extra taxes to the government—so much for the promise of no new taxes! That will impact on employment and on the profitability of that company. There is no doubt in my mind that CRA conceded the Dampier Salt issue because they did not want the diesel fuel rebate to be narrowed to Hamersley Iron and their other major mining concerns. But, if you look at the salt industry in their own right and their entitlement here, they are a major and important industry in the state of Western Australia. They won a long court battle to establish their entitlement. This legislation would simply put at nil all those legal arguments which have been so long in being established.

My fourth reason for opposing this bill is that the taxing agent here is the Customs Service. The Customs Service is a service that I have had more than nodding acquaintance with. It is an admirable service, and I pay recognition to it. But it is not a service that specialises in the mining industry. It does not know this industry well and, in this exercise, it is being sooled onto the mining industry like an attack dog to take whatever money it can—through the guise of the diesel fuel rebate—to meet the target set by the Treasurer for the so‐called black hole. And it has done that with enthusiasm.

As a consequence, this bill is fatally flawed in many respects. There will be massive unintended consequences once it is pro claimed—if it is—and there will be continuing litigation over terms and conditions contained in this legislation, if it becomes law. We have seen a situation where major industry sectors have had to go to court to establish their right. That situation will continue. That is a consequence of a not very thorough and too shallow understanding of the importance, significance and detail of technical matters surrounding how mining is conducted in Australia, of how offshore oil and gas search and development is conducted in this country and of the implications for smaller mining holdings, as well as for farmers in some circumstances.

Let me give the chamber an example of the sorts of complaints that I refer to. A fishing boat sailing out of the port of Dampier is entitled to claim the diesel fuel rebate. A safety boat sailing out of the very same port of Dampier to service the offshore oil rigs—which stands off an oil rig as a legal requirement for safety reasons—cannot claim the diesel fuel rebate under this legislation. That is not just odd; that is unfair. A mandatory government requirement requires that boat to be there if the industry is to carry on its activities at all.

BREAK.PARA: Let me turn to another example. Heavy vehicles on mine sites are able to claim under this legislation, but light vehicles on mine sites are not. That goes to an argument about the type of mine site, the size of the mine and the type of vehicles required. There is no doubt that light vehicles are, in certain circumstances, essential to a mining operation and, where they work on a lease, ought not be discriminated against—and smaller companies ought not be discriminated against.

I said one or two words about the salt industry earlier. The salt industry is an important industry in Australia. They have won a legal entitlement for coverage for this rebate. They are disenfranchised by the legislation if this legislation is to go forward. But they are not the only industry that is caught in that circumstance. The cement industry, which has had legal action on foot to protect its own right, is also now to be, under this legislation, removed from entitlement. It is to be removed from entitlement because of a definition where mining for limestone, as the ore body for calcite, the essential ingredient for the manufacture of cement, is termed as quarrying and not represented as mining.

They are the four reasons that I refer to as to why the opposition does not support this legislation—that this is an example of negative cost cutting; that this breaks an election undertaking; that this breaks in three ways the undertakings that the minister and the government gave when they started talks with the industry about settling what this package would contain; and the inappropriateness of the way in which the Customs Service has defined elements of this industry and the technical problems created under the legislation for that reason.

This has been a bill that the industry has, in evidence before a Senate committee inquiring into this legislation, uniformly panned. It has uniformly panned it because, by narrowing the entitlement for the rebate, the indirect taxes or the input tax which diesel fuel represents is increased on the industry. On the frontispiece of the Mining Council's submission to the Senate Economics Legislation Committee inquiry, there is an illustrative graph of how uncompetitive Australian companies are made against a number of other major mining powers in the world—companies they compete against in the international marketplace.

Australia with a diesel fuel rebate—and that is a full diesel fuel rebate, not the rebate countenanced in this legislation—pays a cost of 28c for diesel fuel. Canada is a major competitor for Australia in the mining industry: it pays 25c. Chile is another major competitor in the mining industry: it pays 24c. Indonesia, a fourth major competitor in this industry, and one in our region, pays 21c. So Australian competitors in the world market for a price sensitive industry are put at a disadvantage by government legislation. Since the minister for resources is at the table I should make the observation that, while he is an active and positive booster for this industry, nonetheless, he is here today as an agent, putting taxes on this industry, which will limit its ability to grow and create employment and jobs in Australia.
