SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wanted to open by referring to comments by Senator Vanstone today in question time. Senator Vanstone, when dealing with some questions about cuts in funding to the Australian Federal Police and a reduction in the number of police, talked about the concept of achieving more with less. I must say that senators on this side of the chamber were somewhat incredulous at that statement and I want to look at that statement in the context of something that is happening in the city of Launceston, the city in which I have my office in the state of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight there is a public meeting taking place. It will commence in about 10 minutes. It is about the Tasmanian fire service and its plans to reduce the suburban fire station at Rocherlea to an office hours operation. I believe there are similar plans which are held for fire stations at Rokeby on the eastern shore of Hobart and the Hobart central fire station.

I must confess that I am somewhat stunned that the fire service can decide that somehow fires should only take place during the hours of eight in the morning to five in the evening Monday to Friday. Residents of the northern suburbs of Launceston, which is the area of Launceston that the Rocherlea fire station occupies, cannot feel comfortable about their safety when, at the times that most people are in their homes, particularly their children, the fire services are proposed to be reduced.

This cut will mean a substantial reduction in the fire protection that the citizens of Launceston will receive, in particular from the Rocherlea professional fire crew. Rocherlea and the neighbouring suburb of Mowbray are high fire risk areas and the reality is that most of these fires occur at night. There are currently only three professional fire crews in Launceston at any given time in a city of 98,000 people.

The plans of the Tasmanian fire service will mean that for 75 per cent of the time there will only be two crews. This is a threat not only to the community but to the firefighters themselves. The ability of firefighters to obtain backup from other crews at emergencies is vital to their safety. If this cut occurs and there are two fires simultaneously in Launceston that will mean that neither crew will have access to a backup crew. They will be left exposed and without help. The Tasmanian fire service is obviously failing in its duty of care in relation to employee safety.

But what of this more with less philosophy? Certainly, a cut in the number of firefighters in Tasmania will lead to a more with less result. Less firefighters means more risk to firefighters' lives. Less firefighters means more risk to the lives of citizens. And less firefighters means more risk of loss of property.

I would like to point out to senators the impact of time in a response to a fire. Within five minutes from observance and notification, fire damage can be limited perhaps to one room in a house and a family may be rescued and resuscitated. If notification and arrival occur within 10 minutes, the fire would most likely have spread to other rooms, causing suffocating and blinding smoke, with the dangers that those circumstances would occasion. Within 15 minutes, many houses would be consumed by fire. The loss of vital minutes can be the difference between minimum damage and extensive damage to property and, more importantly, between life and death.

The Tasmanian fire service has already lost one in 14 of its firefighting officers over the last nine months through natural attrition. Ten years ago there were 50 per cent more firefighters on shift than there are today. The Tasmanian fire service has commenced enterprise bargaining with the employees and this is the result of it. Employees have been offered an eight per cent wage increase over a 25‐month period but must accept cuts across the board to firefighting numbers and fire stations. They must accept a 30 per cent cut in the number of 24‐hour fire stations in the state, with a further one in eight firefighting jobs to go.

The members of the United Firefighters Union of Australia have coined a slogan: `Firefighters save lives, we don't trade them.' The safety of the citizens of Launceston and the hardworking men and women in the fire service are not, in their view, a tradeable item. Enterprise bargaining should be about improvements to service delivery: it should not be about cutting costs for the sake of it.

More with less? An inappropriate philosophy where lives and safety are concerned. I would like to congratulate the United Firefighters Union on their successful rally in Launceston's Civic Square today and say that I wish them well on behalf of the Tasmanian community because what they are fighting for is in the interest of that community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Most senators would know that I have been involved in issues relating to whistleblowing for most of my time in the Senate. In fact, this speech follows one I gave last night, but about a different whistleblower.

SPEECH.PARA: I was a member of the second Senate committee on whistleblowing issues. Many of the cases covered in the committee's inquiry centred around Queensland and I have continued to follow the whistleblowing issue and some of the specific cases with interest. I am concerned about the lack of action on this matter on the part of the coalition since it came into government last year. I believe they gave a pre‐election commitment to do something about the need for greater legislative protection for whistleblowers but so far there appears to have been no action at all.

Part of my purpose in speaking tonight is to remind the government and the public that this is an issue which will not go away and one which needs to be addressed. There has been a lot of concern expressed in recent months about the further decline in public confidence in institutions of government. It is almost in epidemic proportions. That is why action on the part of whistleblowers, for example, would be one positive step which could be taken to reverse this situation. It would give ordinary people more confidence that if they do take issue and blow the whistle they will be protected and that their actions will be complimented instead of their becoming the target of all kinds of retribution.

I indicate to the Senate tonight that it is my intention to introduce a draft bill to protect whistleblowers. I would hope that would be a spur to the government to do what they said they were going to do. We can only hope. This bill will be based on much of the work of the two Senate inquiries—one of which was chaired by Senator Murphy, and chaired very well—and also on the whistleblowers protection bill, which was introduced by another former senator who was very interest ed in whistleblowing, former Senator Chamarette.

No‐one can deny that there are still many examples of corruption and maladministration which need to be exposed. It is important that governments take more action to encourage whistleblowers to come forward and then to protect those who do. Unfortunately, the shoot the messenger approach still seems to be the norm.

I want to make mention tonight of Dr William De Maria, who is a researcher and lecturer at the University of Queensland's social work and social policy department. Dr De Maria gave evidence on his research to the Senate inquiry and has done some pioneering work in researching the case histories of many whistleblowers.

It is important to highlight the value of the work which was done by Dr De Maria and his researchers. His work has focused predominantly on the public sector in Queensland, but there is little doubt that similar problems exist throughout Australia. If I wanted to be paro chial, I could say that universities in Queensland have a tendency to produce high quality research. Certainly, Dr De Maria's work should be seen as bringing credit to the University of Queensland's social work department.

However, there was one disturbing aspect of Dr De Maria's study into whistleblowing which comes not from his report but from the reaction which he received as a consequence of it. This is an illustration of the very problem.

When the details from the study were released, the credibility of the research and the researcher was attacked by the then Premier, Mr Goss. Mr Goss was reported in the Australian newspaper alleging that Dr De Maria had made up details in at least one of the cases contained in his research—a serious accusation. In the state parliament on 12 April 1994, Mr Goss again attacked Dr De Maria, using material provided by the CJC, and again accused him of `frequently giving inaccurate details of whistleblowers' situations to the media'—again, a very serious accusation.

Whilst I support an ongoing role for the CJC in Queensland, I am afraid my experience with whistleblower issues has somewhat dented my confidence in their ability to competently investigate and report on complaints. This is a classic case where the CJC, in response to a request from the Premier, had tried to identify the whistleblower referred to in a newspaper report on Dr De Maria's study. The CJC contacted Dr De Maria and, when he told them that he took the usual steps to protect the identity of whistleblowers when he was speaking about their cases, the CJC reported this in a pejorative way to imply significant falsification of details.

The CJC, in pursuing its investigations to back up its refuting of Dr De Maria's credibility, then provided details of the wrong case to `prove' its point. The real whistleblower concerned in the case later went public to confirm the accuracy of Dr De Maria's research and to support him against this attack on his academic credentials.

BREAK.PARA: There can be few allegations more serious against an academic than that of falsifying research. Unfortunately, Dr De Maria's credibility was attacked in the state parliament in a calculated attempt to undermine his findings and deflect attention from the very serious situation which he uncovered. It is my understanding that, unfortunately, the state parliament does not provide the same opportunity as the Senate in enabling those who believe they have been unfairly maligned in the chamber to put their side of the story. I wish that all parliamentary chambers in this country would do what the Senate does because it is a very necessary and important corrective, but then we lead the way on many of these issues.

I would hope that all senators could affirm the right of academics to speak openly about their research without having to endure attacks and dishonest efforts to undermine their credibility. Such attacks can have serious impacts on an academic's career prospects, particularly in the brave new world of tertiary education into which we have moved in recent years. Dr De Maria certainly believes that this attack on his credibility, and particularly the accusation that he falsified case studies in his research, has done his academic standing long-term damage.

He received extensive coverage in the media over a number of years for the research he has done in this area. His work is important and influential in looking at how we can do better to encourage and protect whistleblowers. As I said before, I believe such achievements reflect well on the University of Queensland and the social work department for which he works. I hope that tertiary institutions support their academics when they are misrepresented or unfairly attacked, particularly when they have the courage to take on politicians and governments.

The important role which whistleblowers play has been highlighted in this Senate many times in recent years. It may seem that attention to this issue has diminished a bit in the last year or so, but I wish to assure the Senate that it is an issue which will not go away and which is as deserving of attention now as it ever has been. The extensive work done by people such as Dr De Maria shows that it is a serious and wide reaching issue which still requires strong action from government at all levels. I intend to build on the work of the Senate committees and other senators in this place and introduce draft legislation in an attempt to better address this crucial matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on a matter of enormous importance to thousands of Victorians. We have heard a great deal over the last few months about the need for certainty. Pastoralists, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) tells us, want to be certain that native title claims do not threaten their livelihood. Well, the Wik decision may or may not have added some uncertainty to the lives of pastoralists, but I want to say tonight that there are no pastoral leases in Victoria but there are many people who live in Victoria's central‐northern region for whom certainty is a thing of the past. I am referring to residents living in Bendigo, Eaglehawk, Kangaroo Flat, Costerfield, Dunolly and other towns who now face the prospect of living with an open cut mine.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year the Herald‐Sun ran a very large feature story, including a full centre page map of Victoria, which identified vast tracts of land north of the ranges where the latest technology had detected traces of gold. Much of this land was worked over during the gold rush which made Victoria so wealthy at the turn of the century. The traces which remain are very small indeed—as little as one‐tenth of a gram of gold in one to two tonnes of soil. Most of the gold was unearthed by very labour intensive mining methods, but today mining technology is of course very different. Explosives, heavy machinery and cyanide all mean that mining for extremely small amounts of gold has again become viable.

Mining companies have moved back into places like Bendigo and Dunolly. They have moved into parts of the town where very often mining had taken place more than a century before. Of course, the major difference now is that people have built their houses, raised families and settled on this land. But these people now face the future as neighbours of enormous open cut mining operations.

Most senators will understand that a mining operation, particularly one which for five years or so uses explosives, heavy earthmoving equipment and trucks, sprays mounds of earth with cyanide and then leaves behind an enormous quarry, will not, by any stretch of the imagination, be a good neighbour. It does not matter how much consultation there is, how many public meetings are held or how many environment effects studies are conducted, one thing is for certain—an open cut mine does not a good neighbour make. The people of northern Victoria want certainty. They do not want to face the future not knowing whether or not the dust from a mine will damage their health and the health of their children.

The Bendigo Community Health Service came out last week opposing the proposed mine at Eaglehawk. The CEO, Dee Watson, said that the mine would put the general public at risk and that dust levels would be unacceptable. The consultant who wrote the environment effects study said in the report that change to the level of dust could have significant consequences for human respiratory systems and pose a threat to human health. As for the use of cyanide, the guidelines used in this EES relate to occupational health and safety. In other words, they relate to the risk posed by mine workers during operations. They are not applicable to the continued exposure that nearby residents will receive.

The people living close to the proposed mine are asking what this means for long-term exposure for them. How will it affect their small children? How will this affect the elderly living in the community? Does anyone care that many have come to this part of the world in order to retire? And what about those who have respiratory problems, many of whom choose to come to the area because of the clean air? What happens to your lungs if you live alongside and breathe in the dust day and night for five years or more? The cheapest way to move earth is to blast it out of the ground. I ask the Senate: how many families would enjoy living alongside regular explosions day in and day out? Thousands of people in northern Victoria are expected to get used to that idea.

The environment effects study says that noise levels will exceed EPA guidelines for some residents. I thought, like most of us, that the EPA at state level would protect us from health‐threatening intrusions of cyanide bearing dust and deafening noise. I am happy to say that the EPA's submission to the panel examining the Eaglehawk mine has at least asked for further information from Bendigo Mining. As I understand it, the EPA in Victoria also has guidelines regarding the distance one should live from a mine site. These guidelines say that mines should not be within 500 metres of houses. But in the Bendigo region some families would be separated from the mine by only the width of a road. If their children play in the street, they will share it with trucks going to and from the mine.

So what are the options for people for whom living alongside a mine is unacceptably dangerous? How certain can they be that the profits from an open cut mining operation will be shared around? How certain will they be of proper compensation should they decide to take their families to safer ground? The answer is that they cannot be certain at all.

Some, but not all, residents in the Bendigo area have been offered compensation. The Mineral Resources Development Act requires the mining licensee to pay compensation for loss of amenity or any decrease in the market value of the property. So how does this work? The mining company has discretion over which, if any, residents will be offered compensation. Bendigo Mining says that it will arrange for a base valuation to be made of the property, two if the first is disputed. Some property owners, however, have already reported that these valuations are well below those used by the council to calculate municipal rates.

Once the base valuation has been established and the mine is under way, the owner can place the property on the market. If it is sold after four months at a discount value— say, 70 per cent below the base valuation—the mining company pays the difference or buys the property. The problem is that not only are residents forced to take the valuation that the mining company dictates but they have to go to very lengthy processes. Judging from experience elsewhere, many will have to take mining companies to appeals tribunals and to courts before any of that compensation is made.

Of course, the Mineral Resources Development Act provides no real certainty either. As I understand it, none of the residents around the mine at Heathcote, for example, received any compensation from the New Holland Mining Company. Of course, even if people can sell their houses, they will not be compensated for the very considerable disruption to their daily lives. Many people now facing this prospect are deeply worried about their future.

The mining industry is littered with examples of mining companies going into liquidation, leaving a trail of destruction in their wake. I have seen first hand the damage done to our very precious and depleted box ironbark forests in northern Victoria, the very fragile soils there and the damage to our waterways, for instance, at Dunolly by fly-by-night mining operations. I have seen farm dams and creeks permanently damaged by mining operations.

I have tried to put to the Senate tonight the concerns of people who face the uncertainty of living alongside mining operations. Of course, I have not even touched on the very important issue of environmental damage done by open cut mining operations, but I do ask you to consider what it would be like for communities right around Victoria to live in and around these deep scars on the countryside. What would it be like to speculate about the damage being done to waterways? What is it like to have whole slabs of public open space where birds and trees used to inhabit converted into deep quarries?

In the current climate in which the dollar is everything, such mines are not rehabilitated. The reality is that holes in the ground 40 metres deep and, in the case of Kangaroo Flat, almost a kilometre long, will be only partially filled. The mining company will only be required to undertake the most minimal planting on the mounded earth around the edges. The mining companies say that to fill the hole and to return the topsoil would be too expensive—it would make the whole operation unviable. I suggest to the Senate that this kind of mining should be unviable. It should be unviable to single out these people to make them pay the very high price of scrounging that last little bit of wealth from the soil.

I urge my fellow Victorian senators to take action on behalf of the people of Bendigo, Kangaroo Flat, Dunolly, Heathcote, Costerfield, and everywhere else where they are being asked to give up so much. The only certainty here in this part of Victoria is that we are chasing fool's gold and the people who are paying are saying that enough is enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of things that I will mention tonight. BREAK.PARA: Madam President, today in the Senate in question time, Senator Gibson asked the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, a question about interest rates. We heard from Senator Kemp about all the benefits that have arisen as a result of the supposed action of this government that has brought about low inflation, which has led to obviously lower interest rates. We have also heard the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) talk about wage restraint having some impact on that. When we were in government, we had a centralised wage fixing process and the then opposition, led by Mr Howard, used to attack us and say that we were driving families' and workers' wages down and that, under a Howard‐led government, they could only do better.

That is very interesting, because I noted Senator Kemp's expansive statement about small businesses and how well they were going to do under the coalition and how well they indeed were doing. Not so, it would appear, certainly according to the latest Yellow Pages survey of small business that says a number of things. One thing it definitely does say is that small business does not think it is doing well under the coalition. In fact, it thinks it is doing damned awfully. Eighty per cent of the people surveyed felt that the economy was either in recession or, at best, at a standstill.

This is a survey of 1,200 businesses so it is not a mickey mouse survey. It is one that coalition members in opposition used many times to try to attack us when we were in government, so they seem to think that it has some relevance and, of course, some accuracy. I will read something about the survey that I took off the monitor today from AAP:
Small business appeared today to desert the Howard government with many ignorant of major coalition initiatives and fearful that the economy was in recession.
The latest Yellow Pages small business index found confidence had weakened to its lowest level since August 1993 . . .

I am not sure where Senator Kemp was getting his information from, but he certainly was not getting it out of the Yellow Pages Small Business Index. The report says that only 40 per cent of small business operators are confident about their prospects in the future, down from 57 per cent a year ago. The survey found that only 37 per cent of business operators were aware of the Howard government's small business package, and of that 37 per cent only 22 per cent felt that there was any advantage in it for them.

So comments from Senator Kemp, as the Assistant Treasurer, and indeed from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Costello) about how well small business is doing under this government ought to be looked at. We can have a look at what small businesses are doing well.

I have to say I congratulate the Treasurer for his attack on the banks. He took some time to get around to it. I find it interesting to note the comments that he made where he says, `Look, if your bank is offering you 7.2 per cent on a standard variable loan, get down to Aussie Home Loans, or get down to RAMS or Priority One.' That would be good if people could. He seems to have forgotten the fact that, when banks lend most people money, those people are locked into a period of time before they can actually pay the loan back. There are early repayment penalty clauses that, in most cases, are such that people simply cannot opt out and say, `Look, if your interest rate is too high, I am going to trot down there and get it off somebody else.' What a nonsense! If the Treasurer is really serious about doing something for consumers in respect of bringing greater and more competition into the banking system, he will do something about things like early repayment penalty clauses.

To go back to this issue of small business and who is doing well, let me tell you who is doing well in terms of small business. These people have the names of Don Argus, Bob Joss and Don Mercer, and there are a few other people in the top echelons of bank management in this country. I have got to say that I do not mind people in those positions earning reasonable salaries and being paid some form of incentive. But, given the Prime Minister's statement about wage restraint and the fact that the government were totally opposed to workers getting $20 a week and they had said that $10 a week was a little bit on the high side, you have got people like Don Argus and Bob Joss.

I just want to refer to Bob Joss's position in terms of his $1.9 million salary and then he has share options that will see him earn over $30 million. They are shares that he has options on, and on which he has to pay no money except that they will be exercised at $2.85 per share—and they are currently worth around $7.50.

Surely that is an unacceptable position. Surely it is unacceptable that banks have $15 billion of depositors' funds, from the battlers that the Prime Minister keeps referring to, that they pay no interest on—none whatsoever. They have a further almost $80 billion—billion, not million—in term deposits that they pay less than two per cent on.

The government introduced legislation, with the support of the Democrats, to introduce retirement savings accounts. They are exactly the type of account that people will be forced to put their money into that will earn them no interest, or at best two per cent interest. And you expect them to be in a position to retire on those sorts of moneys. It is a joke.

Staff across the four major banks—this is staff; not managers, not the top level—hold shares worth about $400 million. But senior management in the four banks hold share options worth a billion dollars.

I have to say that I think that is totally unacceptable, particularly when you consider another issue, withholding tax. The banks are holding moneys that amount to several hundred million dollars that the courts have found the banks illegally took from borrowers, and they are still not repaying those moneys. That relates to a lot of battlers in this country, it relates to a lot of small businesses and it relates to a lot of farmers who would appreciate it very much if the government were to be serious about bringing real reforms into this banking industry. It is not enough just to make populist statements that people should get down to Priority One or some such thing. The government should really do something for people who need assistance. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Prime Minister ought to get in and make the banks repay the money that they are holding illegally. (Time expired)

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The detailed criteria to be fulfilled for areas to continue receiving analogue mobile phone coverage after the planned network closure from 1 January 2000 have yet to be developed. I have announced that the Government will arrange for a review of rural planned service areas to be conducted in 1999. This review will determine which areas receive mobile coverage from an alternative technology (such as GSM, or another technology if available by then) which is reasonably equivalent to (or better than) the quality of service and breadth of coverage provided in that area by AMPS. The detailed criteria used to give effect to this broad principle will be developed as part of the 1999 review. However, in broad terms, it is expected that the criteria will consider the issues of coverage; nature and quality of service; and overall cost to the consumer.

(2) Any areas where analogue AMPS coverage is to be continued after 2000 will be identified following the 1999 review. There is no requirement for local areas or government bodies to nominate themselves for retention of AMPS coverage.

(3) At this stage it is not possible to indicate whether the Shire of Coolamon will continue to receive an analogue service after 2000. As noted above, any areas where analogue AMPS coverage is to be continued after 2000 will be identified following the 1999 review.

(4) At this stage it is not possible to provide a list of all sites that will be eligible to continue on analogue services after 2000. Following completion of the 1999 review a list of any sites that will be eligible to continue on analogue services after 2000 will be publicly available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 26 March 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the eleventh anniversary, on 26 April 1997, of the 1986 Chernobyl disaster involving a subsequent 200‐fold increase in regional childhood thyroid cancers, a 160 per cent increase in the incidence of birth defects, a 45 per cent increase in breast cancers and the contamination of large parts of eastern and western Europe:
(1) Can details be provided of the progress in negotiations on the Convention on Supplementary Funding for Transboundary Nuclear damage from Nuclear Incident at a Civil Nuclear Power Plant.

(2) What would the effect of this Convention be in the case of a nuclear accident or mistake in a south‐east Asian civil nuclear power plant which sent a cloud of radioactive waste over Australia, or discharged nuclear contamination into Australian waters.

(3) In the case of nuclear power plant accidents to foreign warships visiting Australian ports and coastal waters: (a) what formal arrangements are in place for physically responding to the health and environmental emergency, in each Australian port, and in general coastal waters; and (b) what formal arrangements are in place for countries which send visiting warships to Australia to fund the immediate and consequential costs of such a nuclear accident.

(4) As a result of British nuclear tests in the 1950s in Australia: (a) what are the current locations and land areas contaminated by radioactive substances; (b) what is the severity of contamination in each location; and (c) what is the period in which they are expected to be uninhabitable.
(5) What plans does the Government have to assist, facilitate, broker or support, directly or through third partners, the selling of uranium to Indonesia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The International Atomic Energy Agency's Standing Committee on Nuclear Liability concluded negotiations on the Supplementary Funding Convention for compensation of nuclear damage in Vienna on 11 April 1997. The meeting adopted a clean text of the draft Convention, which will be considered at a Diplomatic Conference yet to be scheduled. The major issues for discussion at the final meeting of the Standing Committee were entry into force, jurisdiction in the exclusive economic zone and the definition of damage, all of which have been resolved in a manner consistent with Australia's objectives for the negotiations. The final draft Convention includes a compensation fund dedicated to transboundary harm, and a broad definition of damage.

(2) The draft Convention will supplement and enhance the provisions of the Vienna and Paris Conventions, including by increasing compensation for transboundary harm, and providing compensation for environmental damage.

Both the Vienna and Paris Conventions are based on the exclusive and strict liability of the operator of a nuclear installation, on limitation of liability in amount and in time, and on the jurisdiction of the courts of the state within whose territory the nuclear installation is situated. They provide for a minimum amount of compensation and for financial coverage through insurance or other financial security. In the event of a nuclear incident involving a nuclear power plant in the region following the entry into force of the draft Convention, if Australia and the state in which the accident occurred were parties to the Convention and Australian interests were affected by radioactive material released as a result of the incident, Australia would be able to claim compensation for transboundary harm falling within the definition of damage outlined in the Convention. Importantly, this would include compensation for damage to the environment.

(3) (a) At present the only ports approved for visits by nuclear powered warships are Albany, Brisbane, Darwin, Fremantle (Gage Roads and HMAS Stirling), Hobart and Jervis Bay. Visits are only permitted by US and UK nuclear powered warships.

Each of these ports has a safety plan, developed by the State/Territory Emergency Service organisations, designed to protect the public in the very unlikely event of a reactor accident. These safety plans are reviewed by the Visiting Ships Panel (Nuclear), a Commonwealth inter‐departmental committee, on a regular basis.

(b) To cover the unlikely event of a reactor accident aboard a nuclear powered warship in an Australian port, the US and UK Governments have given certain guarantees. Under United States Public Law 93‐513 it is policy to accept liability on an absolute basis for nuclear damage which results from an accident involving the reactor of a US warship. The United Kingdom has provided unilateral assurance to Australia on nuclear liability comparable to that given by the US.

(4) (a) During the 1950s 12 British nuclear weapon tests were conducted in Australia at the Monte Bello Islands (Western Australia) and Emu and Maralinga (South Australia). These tests resulted in measurable radioactivity over large areas of Australia. An Australian Radiation Laboratory report published in 1992, Public Health Impact of Fallout from British Nuclear Weapon Tests in Australia, 1952‐57, found the average radiation dose from nuclear test fallout to be a very small fraction of the average radiation dose from natural sources over this period.

(b) and (c) All areas contaminated by these nuclear tests are now suitable for permanent habitation except small areas of land in the immediate vicinity of detonation sites. Detonation sites will be suitable for unrestricted occupation early in the next century with the exception of the ground zero areas of two tests in the Monte Bello Islands and the Tadje site at Maralinga. The potential hazard presented by permanent habitation at these latter sites has been addressed in site management measures.

In the 1960s, the Vixen B trials at Maralinga left land close to the detonation sites seriously contaminated with plutonium. These areas are currently being rehabilitated as part of the Maralinga Rehabilitation Project.

(5) Indonesia has yet to decide whether or not to embark on a civil nuclear power program. Any future sales of uranium to Indonesia would be a commercial matter for Australian producers, subject to the necessary nuclear safeguards arrangements being in place. The Government currently has no plans to negotiate a bilateral safeguards agreement with Indonesia, and, although the proposed Nuclear Science and Technology Cooperation Agreement with Indonesia does foreshadow the possibility of future uranium transfers, it recognises that a bilateral safeguards agreement would need to be in place for such transfers to occur.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 10 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What programs and or grants administered by the Minister's portfolio provide assistance to people living in the following federal electorates: (a) the Northern Territory; (b) Kalgoorlie; (c) Leichhardt; (d) Herbert; (e) Kennedy; and (f) Capricornia.

(2) (a) What was the level of funding provided through the programs or grants in (1) to each electorate for the 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 financial years; and (b) what level of funding was budgeted for in each electorate for each program or grant for the 1996‐97 financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Pensions and allowances are provided to entitled veterans and dependants, including those living in the specified electorates.
Treatment is also provided to entitled veterans and dependants living in the electorates.

The Training and Information Program provides training and information about Veterans' Affairs benefits and services, legislation and procedures to members of the ex‐service organisations who assist veterans and their dependants. Ex‐service organisations in the specified electorates are assisted by this program.

The Claims Assistance Grants Scheme provides assistance to ex-service organisations throughout Australia to obtain resources such as computer equipment, accommodation and trained officers which they need to assist veterans and their dependants in accessing Veterans' Affairs benefits and services. The Scheme was an initiative announced in the 1996‐97 Budget.

The Their Service—Our Heritage commemorative program provides funding for purposes such as commemorative events, public awareness, education, memorial projects and battlefield revisitation. The aim of the program is to involve as many Australians as possible in commemorative activities and projects. Grants made under this program have replaced those made through the Minister's Discretionary Fund and the Australia Remembers 1945‐1995 program.

The Residential Care Development Scheme improves the access of entitled veterans and their widow(er)s to high quality residential aged care services and community aged care packages and helps the ex‐service organisations to continue their role in providing residential and innovative aged care services. The Scheme subsumed the Hostel Development Scheme in 1995‐96.

The Joint Venture Scheme maintains and improves the independence and quality of life of the veteran community by assisting ex‐service organisations to provide social and personal support services, in particular to those organisations which do not have the capacity to fund projects themselves.

The Community Care Seeding Grants Program maintains and improves the independence and quality of life of veterans and their widow(er)s living in the community by increasing access to community care services and residential and community‐based respite care. The Program was introduced in 1995‐96.
The Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service (VVCS) provides counselling and support for veterans and their families residing in both metropolitan and rural and remote areas across Australia.
Services are provided for veterans and their families in rural and remote areas under the Coun‐
try Outreach Program which allows access to contracted professional counselling services in their locations, administratively supported by VVCS staff from designated VVCS centres.

A number of programs have also been developed under the Younger Veterans Program including residential lifestyle courses, specialised group courses and involvement in the treatment and ongoing management of veterans with chronic conditions such as post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), with strong links to intensive hospital-based treatment programs.

Support is also provided from VVCS centres. Services in the Northern Territory are based in Darwin; services for Kalgoorlie are predominantly based in Perth with some support from Darwin; services for Leichhardt and Herbert are based in Townsville; services for Kennedy are predominantly based in Townsville with support from Brisbane; and services for Capricornia are based in Brisbane.
The Health Promotion Program helps the veteran community adopt healthier lifestyles to prevent illness and improve their health and quality of life.

Veterans' Health Week is an annual event sponsored by my Department. It aims to assist veterans towards a greater awareness of relevant health issues and to help change the behaviour of veterans toward healthier lifestyles to prevent illness and improve health and quality of life.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 6 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: What criteria are used to determine whether spouses of senators and members who have been invited to a dinner to honour a visiting head of
state or head of government are also issued with an invitation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: As a general rule, the criterion used is that if a visiting head of state or head of government is accompanied by his/her spouse, the spouses of senators and members who have been invited to the dinner are also issued with an invitation.
